dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well worn teddy-bear is cradled in the arms of Napoleon age 4, who dreamily sucks his thumb, listening to a bedti story told by his young mother, Letizia. His 5-year old brother, Joseph, is already asleep, beside him.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon was born at Ajaccio in Corsica on August 15th, 1769. He had not been a healthy baby and his mother, Letizia, lavished him with care and devotion. In middle age, he would write about her from St. Helena.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mother has always loved me. She would do anything for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is still dark on a freezing winter morning. The boys a being awakened by a monk, loudly ringing a bell. Candles lit. Napoleon, age 9, sun-tanned, leaps out of bed, rubbing hi arms and shivering. He tries to pour a pitcher of water, discovering that it has frozen solid.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Who has been putting glass in my pitcher? Look here, someone has filled my pitcher with glass!

dialogues.speaker: DUFOUR
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness! Someone has filled Bonaparte's pitcher with glass. Now, who on earth would do a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: BREMOND
dialogues.text: Oh, heavens, look someone has filled my pitcher with glass too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence! Silence! You should not make fun of Monsieur Bonaparte, he comes from a country where it is never very cold. He has probably never seen ice before.

dialogues.speaker: DUFOUR
dialogues.text: Never seen ice before? Oh, dear me -- how very odd. The boys snicker. Napoleon glares at them.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: At the age of 9, Napoleon entered the Royal Military College at Brienne, in France, under a royal scholarship. For the next five and a half years, he would devote himself to preparation for his military career. These were harsh and cheerless years for the lonely, impoverished provincial, among affluent French noblemen's sons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lovely, late-summer afternoon. A small group of boys, i their school uniforms, are impatiently gathered around a rough table, covered with stacks of thick bread and jam a tin mugs of milk. The farmer's wife supervises things, collecting a sou from each boy. Napoleon, 9, stands apart from the group, drinking his mi a book under his arm, lost in thought, gazing across the cornfield at the school buildings, which are beautifully colored by the late sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOND
dialogues.text: (overly cheerful) Good afternoon, Bonaparte. Napoleon ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOND
dialogues.text: What are you reading? No reply. Dufour moves behind Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOND
dialogues.text: (angling his head to read the title) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREMOND (cont'd) Dear me, aren't we in an unfriendly mood. Caesar's conquest of Gaul. Aren't we terribly conscientious about our studies? By the way, did the supervisor give you permission to take that book away from the school grounds?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (quietly) Fuck off, Bremond.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOND
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness. What language! Did you learn that from your mother, Bonaparte? Bremond is 4 years older and much bigger than Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Fuck off! At this moment, Dufour gives him a violent bump from behi spilling milk all over his uniform and splattering the bo

dialogues.speaker: DUFOUR
dialogues.text: Oh, goodness, my dear Bonaparte -- I am clumsy. Oh, and look at your book! Napoleon hurls the tin cup, with all his strength, at Duf hitting him squarely on the forehead, with a resonant pon mnng! Napoleon leaps on Bremond, and the two boys go down a tangle of bread, jam and milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, age 16, being fitted for his smart, 2nd Lieutenant's uniform, studies himself in the full-length mirror.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: At the age of 16, he graduated a sub-lieutenant from the Royal Military School in Paris, and was posted to the crack regiment de la Fere, at Valence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Artillery firing range. A hot summer morning. Napoleon is part of a group of young officers loading and firing a cannon.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The practical professional training that Napoleon would receive for the next three years would give hima working knowledge of all arms, and expose him to the advanced military ideas of du Teil, Bourcet and Guibert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A calm, winter day, snow on the ground. Napoleon and grou go through the ordered drill of loading and firing a musk Their targets are painted figures of soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The edge of a wood near Valence. A windy, spring day. Napoleon and nine other young officers are gathered aroun leathery-looking Captain with steel spectacles, who is instructing them in the art of map reading. The map, abou four feet wide, is flapping noisily in the heavy gusts of wind, despite the four pairs of knees and hands strugglin hold it flat against the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon's room at Valence. It is filled with books, most of military subjects, but well-stocked with poetry, histo and philosophy. He is reading by candlelight. Outside we hear the sounds of revelry produced by less conscientious officers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His moods at this time were complex and varied.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Life is a burden for me. Nothing gives me any pleasure; I find only sadness in everything around me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAPOLEON (V.O.) (cont'd) It is very difficult because the ways of those with whom I live, and probably always shall live, are as different from mine as moonlight is from sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, 17, the youngest of a group of a dozen officers are seated around a table in the local inn, drinking and singing songs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a hazy, summer dawn. Napoleon, 17, and Caroline Columbier, a lovely young girl of 15, walk together in a forest. They occasionally stop to pick cherries. It is a scene of pre-Raphaelite innocence and beauty -- the young officer, smartly uniformed, the innocent girl in a flowin white dress.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He made friends with a family called Columbier, and would later write of his first flirtation with their daughter, Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It will scarcely be considered credible, perhaps, but our whole business consisted in eating cherries together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a witheringly cold winter night, in Lyon. People, bundled up to the eyes, hurry along the almost deserted street, past empty cafes which are still open. Napoleon, hands deep in his pockets, shoulders hunched against the cold, passes a charming, young street-walker, about his own age. He stops and looks at her, uncertainly A large snowflake lands on her nose which makes him smile

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mademoiselle. She is sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weather is terrible, isn't it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. It must be one of the worst nights we have had this winter.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes, it must be. Napoleon is at a loss for conversation.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You must be chilled to the bone, standing out of doors like this.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes, I am, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Then what brings you out on such a night?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Well, one must do something to live, you know -- and I have an elderly mother who depends on me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh, I see... That must be a great burden.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: One must take life as it comes -- do you live in Lyon, sir?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No, I'm only here on leave. My regiment is at Valence.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you staying with a friend, sir?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No... I have a... room... at the Hotel de Perrin.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Is it a nice warm room, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it must be a good deal warmer than it is here on the street.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Would you like to take me there, so that we can get warm, sir?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Uh-hh... yes, of course -- if you would like to go... there... but... I have very little money.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you have three francs, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon's cheap hotel room is only slightly warmer than street. A candle flickers in the draft, and the driving s forms a lovely vignettes on the window panes. Napoleon sits fully dressed, still wrapped in his coat, scarf, gloves and hat, watching the girl hurriedly undressing, shivering, teeth chattering, and diving into ice-cold bed.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Br-rrr, these sheets are like ice.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry about that. The girl shivers and waits for him to follow her into bed doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Lisette.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Only Lisette?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Lisette La Croix.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: That's a very nice name. Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir, come into bed or I shall die of a chill.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh, yes... of course. He stands and blows out the candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is jammed with 300 peasants and town workers. Many are women, Monsieur Varlac, the revolutionary leader, stands cart flanked by a small Revolutionary Committee. He is muscular, bald man in his forties, wearing glasses. Behind him, we see six severed heads, stuck on pikes.

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: Citizens, word has come from Paris that the foul prison of the Bastille has been captured. (cheers ) That its Governor's head is up on a pike. (cheers ) All Paris is now in the hands of its people. (cheers ) Soon all France will be in the hands of its people. (cheers ) As the cheers die down, we hear the sounds of a solitary drum and marching men. All eyes turn to the appearance of column of 25 French troops, led by Napoleon on a horse an single drummer, marching into the town square in a column threes. Napoleon halts them just inside the square, and rides forward, alone, into the huge crowd, who gives way for hi horse. He stops about 10 feet from Varlac's cart. The man of the people stands, hands on hips, glaring at Napoleon, is now completely surrounded by the crowd. Varlac and his committee converse in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: Good day to our brothers-in-arms. Have you come to join us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am looking for Monsieur George Varlac who resides in the Rue de Frelicot. Do you know him, monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: Very well, Citizen Lieutenant. You have come to the right place, for I am Citizen Varlac. The crowd laughs in an ugly way.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Contrary to what you have been telling these good people, Monsieur Varlac, France is still in the hands of its proper authorities, and they have sent me here with a warrant for your arrest. You are charged with the murder of Monseigneur de Bouchy and his son, and the burning of his chateau. Varlac whispers to several of the men standing around him One of them disagrees and forcefully shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: A revolution is not a polite discussion in a parlor, Citizen Lieutenant. One does not call it murder to kill such vermin.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (speaking for the crowd) You may save your philosophy for the magistrate, Monsieur Varlac. I am only a simple officer in the army, and to me what you have done is called murder, and his always been called murder by honest men.

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: Then do you propose to arrest all of us, Citizen Lieutenant? For I was not there alone.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No, Monsieur Varlac, my warrant is only for you. Now, will you please come down at once. You will be taken back to Chalon for trial. Varlac and his committee talk in agitated whispers.  10.

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: Citizen Lieutenant, my advice is to leave this town at once with your men. We do not wish to do harm to our brothers in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Monsieur Varlac, do not pretend to speak for these good people whom you have misled and inflamed with violent speech. Now, I order you to come down from the cart. Another whispered conference.

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: I do not recognize the authority of the King or any of his lackeys. Laughter from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: VARLAC
dialogues.text: I suggest that you leave with your men while you can.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (drawing his pistol) Monsieur Varlac, I will count slowly to five, and if you have not begun to get down from the cart by then, I will carry out your execution, on the spot. Without giving Varlac time for further discussion, he beg the count.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: One... Two... Three... Several of the committee move away from Varlac.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Four... This is your last chance, Monsieur Varlac. Varlac is frightened, but make an obscene gesture. The cr laughs nervously.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Five... Napoleon rides up to the cart, carefully aims his revolve and shoots Varlac in the head. His entourage leaps to safety.  11. A gasp of astonishment from the stunned crowd, who stand hypnotized.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: A confessed murderer has just been shot. Now, let all honest men return to their homes. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mob of several thousand have broken in and forced Louis XVI, Marie-Antoinette and their children out onto a balco Derisive cheers come from the multitude in the courtyard below. A dozen or so men of the revolution have crowded o on to the balcony, pressing the King and Queen on all sid No one seems to know what to do next. Louis XVI gives a h hearted wave to the crowd. A bottle of champagne and some glasses are brought out. T glasses are courteously handed to the Royal couple. The revolutionaries raise their glasses. The King and the Que drink with them. This creates an uproar of approval from crowd. Then one of the men pulls off his dirty, red stocking cap offers it to the King. Louis XVI stands and looks at it blankly. The revolutionary reaches over and puts it on hi head. The crowd cheers.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Incredible... Incredible... How could he let that rabble into the Palace? If he had ridden out among them on a white horse, they would all have gone home. If he lacked the courage to do that, a whiff of grapeshot -- and they would still be running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The harbor filled with British ships.  12.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In the summer of 1793, Civil war swept through France, and the important naval base at Toulon fell into the hands of a Royalist insurrection, which quickly handed over the port to a combined British and Spanish fleet.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: A French army of 10,000 was ordered to retake the port, but its commander, General Carteaux, a well- known Parisian painter, had little experience in war and the siege quickly became a stalemate. General Carteaux, a florid and moustached man in his late thirties, painting from life, a group of French soldiers, posed in a patriotic tableau, their eyes fixed on a dista vision of glory. In the background, are the tents and the military bustle Carteaux's headquarters, set upon a hill overlooking the harbor of Toulon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smart French honor guard and military band is assembled outside General Carteaux's headquarters for the arrival o Paul Barras, Deputy from the Committee of Public Safety. Barras exits his carriage, accompanied by four foppish ai and embraces General Carteaux. Barras is a virile, handsome, bisexual man with elegant manners of the Ancien Regime. Napoleon is an onlooker with other officers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Paul Francois Nicolas Barras, former Viscount, now Citizen Deputy from the Committee of Public Safety, had been sent from Paris to personally report on the failure of the Siege.  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large table has been set up in the middle of the tent, which are seated Paul Barras, his four civilian aides and generals. Set up at one end of the table is a large military map of Toulon, pinned to a board. Standing back from the table, and ranging along the walls the tent, are 30 junior officers, the staff and aides of generals seated. Napoleon, now a captain of artillery, is with that group. Barras slowly squares up a stack of reports before him an speaks.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Citizen generals, I have read all your reports and noted your signatures. In substance, your views are unanimous. The English positions, defending Toulon, are too strong to be taken by our present force. The two unsuccessful attacks to date would appear to support your arguments. He looks around the table.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Citizen generals, it is no secret with what displeasure the Committee of Safety looks upon any lack of patriotism or revolutionary zeal. On the other hand, it obviously does not wish to indulge in a futile waste of life. Before I send your reports to Paris for the Committee's review, together with my opinion, I should like to give you a final opportunity to present any new ideas which you may have developed since writing these reports. There is troubled silence, but the generals stand pat.  14.

dialogues.speaker: CARTEAUX
dialogues.text: Citizen Barras, since there does not seem to have been any new thoughts among us, may we know the opinion which you, yourself, have formed?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: General Carteaux, my report on the conduct of this campaign will go in writing to the committee. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Citizen Barras. All eyes go to Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Yes -- who spoke up?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I did, sir. Napoleon speaks with the uncomfortable yet determined man that shy but willful people often exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain? Have you anything you wish to say?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (clearing his throat) Yes, with all due respect, I do Citizen Barras.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: May I come to the map?

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Napoleon's plan for the capture of Toulon. Explaining with narration how, rather than trying to capture the tow storm, it is, instead, only necessary to capture Fort Eguillette, a promontory of land from which French batter would command the inner and outer harbors of the port, ma them untenable to the English fleet, and quickly leading the fall of the city.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold December day. The French tricolor is being raised atop the main battery position on Fort Eguillette, a flat area atop a hill, fortified with planks of wood and wickerwork. French gunners have already swung a few pieces of artille to face the harbor and fire on the English ships, now wel within range. Napoleon wheels around on a white horse, shouting orders bloody bandage wrapped around his thigh. The wounded of b sides are being cared for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine, winter day in a field near the military barracks Toulon. Several hundred troops have been drawn up to form honor guard for the presentation of Napoleon's commission Brigadier General. Spectators stand under the bare trees, and little boys watch from atop an embankment. Barras presents Napoleon with his commission and a frater embrace. The band strikes up. Napoleon's mother watches from a small wooden reviewing s which has been prepared for local dignitaries and officer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robespierre lies severely wounded on a conference table, a disarray of papers, surrounded but ignored by his capto who lounge about, seated on chairs, waiting to be told wh to do next.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In July of 1794, the death of Robespierre ended the Reign of Terror and sent Paris headlong into a lavish whirl of pleasure seeking and sensuality, as if it were necessary to shake off the nightmare and make up for lost time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, elegant salon in the house of Paul Barras, in Pa There are ten card tables set up in the room, around whic are gathered the elite of the new society;  16. politicians, immensely rich war contractors, high ranking army officers and government officials. Many of the women are extremely beautiful, and display th breast completely uncovered, in the fashion of the day. Napoleon is one of the few guests not playing cards; he h no money. I11 at ease, he drifts from table to table, han clasped behind his back. Josephine de Beauharnais is the most beautiful of all the women in the room. Napoleon settles at her table, rocking slowly on his heels. She plays for very high stakes and i losing gracefully. She glances up, distracted momentarily his rocking, but her look lasts no longer than the flick card. But Napoleon notices her annoyance and moves off to the b at one end of the room. The bartender, a friendly creep, stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: A glass of champagne, please.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: (pouring) Yes, sir. I hope you will excuse me for asking, General Bonaparte, but are you Corsican?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: I thought so, I noticed your name when you were announced. I'm Corsican too -- my name is Arena.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (starting to move away) Oh -- where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: Bastia -- and you?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ajaccio.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: Have you been back recently?  17. The bartender just manages to keep the conversation going

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I haven't been there for three years.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: I haven't been back for ten years. Is your family still there?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No, they're living in Nice now.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: That's a nice city. This is your first time here, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, as a matter of fact, it is.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: You don't know many of Citizen Barras' friends, do you?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ah-hh, no.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: I thought not. I noticed you by yourself, all night. Napoleon nods, sips his champagne and starts to move away The Corsican leans forward and speaks in a confidential whisper, scanning the room with a deadpan expression.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: Just a minute, General. Listen, don't let them fool you with all their grand la-de-da. They've all made their money from the war -- mostly from crooked war contracts. They say Citizen Barras has put away millions.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) I see... The Corsican whispers without any facial expression, hard moving his lips, without any sense of malice, but more wi kind of shrewd respect for the big-shots, and a satisfact of being in on the know.  18.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: And they say something else about him. They say he never goes to bed with less than two at a time -- two at a time, and they say it doesn't make a lot of difference to him which sex they are, if you follow my meaning, sir. Napoleon nods, awkwardly, and leaves the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CORSICAN
dialogues.text: Have a nice evening, General. Barras enters the room, stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: My friends, dinner will be ready in half an hour. Please make your plays accordingly. His announcement draws only some mock cheers with low mur from the losers. He comes up behind Josephine and kisses on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: (softly) How is your luck, darling? Josephine slowly fans her cards to see the draw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later in the evening, the guests are now assembled in cha grouped in a semi-circle around two raised rostrums -- on really more of a small stage. The smaller rostrum support string quartet playing Mozart. The larger one is empty. Napoleon sits at the back of the room, still alone and awkward. Servants snuff out the candles, leaving only the empty st illuminated. It begins to look like a musical evening until the entran onto the stage of three very attractive girls, dressed in heavy winter costumes. The three "actresses" begin to talk about being snowbound a desolate cabin, when their conversation is interrupted the entrance of three young desperados.  19. The purpose of this entertainment quickly reveals itself the young men proceed to strip off the girls' clothing an have intercourse with them. The distinguished audience sits coolly appreciative of th "sextet." Napoleon, still the provincial, can scarcely believe his eyes. Josephine, seated next to Barras, watches the proceedings imperturbable study of elegance and charm. Barras takes h hand and smiles at her. She whispers something to him and nods, gravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mob, carrying royalist signs, is jammed into a side str their exit barred by a few hundred government troops. Thi have come to a standstill, and the front ranks of the opposing forces have begun to exchange crude, but not unfriendly, jokes. A table and two chairs, from a nearby cafe, have been pla in the middle of the street, dividing the two groups. Sea at it are General Danican, the emigre leader of the mob, General Menou, his government opposite number. Danican is reading over some handwritten sheets of paper which repre an improvised treaty between the two forces. General Meno sips a cup of coffee, looking worried and uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: A new political crisis was brewing in Paris. The moderate government of the Convention, which came to power after the fall of Robespierre, soon showed itself to be inept, corrupt and unpopular -- and it was now faced with a serious challenge from the royalists. General Menou, sent out to deal with the mob, lost his nerve and agreed to withdraw his troops from the Section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the same evening. Napoleon, Junot and Marmont stand a crowd, listening to a Royalist speaker, who stands atop wagon, against a carefully painted sign, illuminated by torches, reading "Long Live the King."  20.

dialogues.speaker: ROYALIST SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Citizens of Paris, this morning, the troops of the Convention, under orders to sweep us from the streets, gave way before our victorious banners. (cheers ) Their officers knew they would not fire upon us. Citizens of Paris, nothing can stop us now. We are strong. Tomorrow morning, we will occupy the Convention itself, and we will exterminate the hypocritical parasites who have bled France without pity. (cheers ) Long Live the King!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barras' office in the Tuileries. The room is lit by candl Barras is in a terrible state, ashen from fear and lack o sleep. Napoleon enters. Barras rises from his desk and comes forward to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear friend, come in, come in. Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I was at the theater and I didn't receive your note until I returned to my hotel.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming. Would you care for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No, thank you. Barras shakily pours a large brandy for himself, speaking subdued and apprehensive tones, frequently running his ha through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: I don't have to tell you of our latest difficulties.  21.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Things are quite serious, I should say.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: We expect an attack on the Convention tomorrow morning, at daybreak, and I have been placed in charge of its defense.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What do you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: To be perfectly honest, I haven't the vaguest idea.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: I don't even know whether a defense is possible.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What forces do you have at your disposal?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: About 5,000 troops.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Cavalry?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: The 21st Dragoons, about two or three-hundred troopers.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Any cannon?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: There are none here.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Well, I believe there are at least guns at Sablons.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You could have them here by daybreak.  22.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Is this enough to oppose 40,000 men?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Properly arranged, yes.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: These are odds of 8 to 1.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: The numbers are not particularly relevant. You are not up against soldiers -- this is a mob, and they will run as soon as things become sufficiently unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Would you be prepared to handle this for me?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Are you proposing to transfer command to me?

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: In every practical sense, yes, but, officially, of course, I would have to retain command.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: I must be honest with you. I first approached three generals more senior than yourself, and they all very prudently sent excuses.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I'm not insulted.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: You realize what is at stake?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (smiling) Our lives, the revolution, my career?  23.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAS
dialogues.text: Look, let me be completely open with you, I have a carriage and an escort waiting for me, and I have a great deal of money outside of France. Unless we stand a very good chance of carrying this off, I am prepared to call it quits right now. Napoleon puts his arms around Barras' shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Paul, everything will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dreamlike, slow-motion shots of the cannon firing point b into the mob on the Rue St. Honore, outside the Conventio They are devastated and there is immediate panic. Murat's cavalry charges them, and the infantry follows wi fixed bayonets. There is no sound of the guns. The only sound is Napoleon's calm voice:

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I ordered the artillery to fire ball immediately, instead of blanks, because, to a mob, who are ignorant of fire arms, it is the worst possible policy to start out firing blanks. When they first hear the terrific noise of the guns, they are frightened, but, looking around them and seeing no effect from the cannon, they pick up their spirits, become twice as insolent and rush on fearlessly. It becomes necessary then to kill ten times their number to make an impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon's new plush headquarters in Paris. Pencil betwee his teeth, dividers in one hand, he creeps around on hand and knees on top of a very large map of Italy, laid out f wall to wall. Other large maps cover the table, the couch and any other available space.  24. Murat, Marmont, Junot and Berthier creep around with him, working out various march routes. Appropriate ad lib dialogue will cover the action. At one point, Napoleon and Berthier bump heads.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The crisis was over, and the way was paved for the formation of the new government of the Directory, with Barras at its head. Napoleon was made Commander of the Army of Italy. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARMONT
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Captain, but there is a young man outside who wishes to see General Bonaparte -- his name is Eugene de Beauharnais.

dialogues.speaker: MARMONT
dialogues.text: General Bonaparte is seeing no one this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (without looking up) What did you say his name was?

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Eugene de Beauharnais.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Is he alone?

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Show him in. The orderly shows Eugene into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Citizen de Beauharnais.  25. Eugene is 16, handsome, well-mannered and extremely nervo Napoleon remains hunched over his map.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (after some silence) Good morning, Citizen de Beauharnais.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. Are you General Bonaparte?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I am, Citizen. Is your mother Madame Josephine de Beauharnais?

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Are you acquainted with her?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I have met her. What is your business with me?

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: I believe you issued an order that all citizens of Paris must hand over any weapons that they have in their possession.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: This morning, a Lieutenant and three soldiers came to our house and asked if we had weapons. I explained we had only my late father's sword, which, in fact, was not a weapon but only a keepsake of memory.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (marking the map) A sword is a weapon whatever else you might wish to use it for.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: I told the Lieutenant my late father was General Alexander de Beauharnais, and asked if there was any consideration that might be given to his memory.  26.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And he sent you to me?

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: He said no one had the authority to rescind the order except you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Does your mother know you have come?

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, then, you have a lot of initiative, my young friend.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: My father's sword means more to me than any other possession I have.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You realize, of course, that thousands of swords have been collected. How do you expect me to find yours? Eugene removes a slip of paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant gave me a receipt for it and said it would be kept at the Section Le Pelletier Police Barracks.

dialogues.speaker: GARDEN
dialogues.text: The garden at Josephine's house on Rue de Chanterine. Napoleon enters, carrying a very strange-looking package, wrapped in paper, about three-feet long, following Horten de Beauharnais, age 16.

dialogues.speaker: HORTENSE
dialogues.text: Mama, this is General Bonaparte.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (bowing) Madame de Beauharnais.  27.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Ah, how nice to meet you, General Bonaparte. One has read so much about you lately. Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Madame de Beauharnais. You probably don't recall but we met briefly a few months ago, at a party at Paul's house.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh... yes, of course! Have you met my daughter, Hortense?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, we introduced ourselves at the door.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: May I offer you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't want to put you to any inconvenience.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not the slightest inconvenience, General Bonaparte. It is an honor to have you here.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You are very kind, Madame de Beauharnais. Do you have some sherry, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Hortense, darling, will you tell Louise to bring some sherry?

dialogues.speaker: HORTENSE
dialogues.text: Yes, mama. Will you excuse me, General Bonaparte?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Hortense exits.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I hope you will forgive me for barging in on you like this, Madame de Beauharnais. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAPOLEON (cont'd) I called to bring this to your son, but I understand from your charming daughter that he is out for the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm afraid he is. I believe he is riding. I know he'll be heartbroken to have missed you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure that you will be just as pleased to have this as he will be. Holding out the package.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: General Bonaparte, my curiosity is unbearable. May I ask what you have in that mysterious package? Napoleon proudly unwraps the paper with a flourish and ho the huge sword with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Your late husband's sword, Madame, returned with my compliments. The paper starts to blow away and Napoleon steps on it. Josephine stares at the sword, blankly.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh... how very nice of you to bring that for Eugene... Did General de Beauharnais give it to you?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid I never had the pleasure of meeting the General. This sword was taken several days ago from your son by some of my soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh, you must forgive me, General Bonaparte, I'm afraid you will think me incredibly stupid but I know absolutely nothing about this. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEPHINE (cont'd) Eugene is so independent -- he hardly tells me anything any more, and he has so many things in his room, I must confess I wasn't even aware that he had this sword -- you know how boys can be! They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The candlelit, oval bedroom is completely encircled with floor-to-ceiling mirrored panels, which multiply the erot images of Napoleon and Josephine, making love. Napoleon's voice, reading the letter below, is heard over scene.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dearest Josephine -- I awaken full of you. Between your portrait and the memory of our intoxicating night, my senses have had no respite. Sweet and incomparable Josephine, what is this bizarre effect you have upon my heart? What if you were to by angry? What if I were to see you sad or troubled? Then my soul would be shattered by distress. Then your lover could find no peace, no rest. But I find none, either, when I succumb to the profound emotion that overwhelms me, when I draw up from your lips, from your heart, a flame that consumes me. You will be leaving the city at noon. But I shall see you in three hours. Until then, mio dolce amor, I send you a thousand kisses -- but send me none in return, for they set my blood on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marriage of Napoleon and Josephine -- a small private civil ceremony in the Mayor's officer. The only guests ar Barras, Eugene, Hortense, Marmont and Junot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dear Theresa -- I am being urged to remarry. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEPHINE (V.O.) (cont'd) You have met General Bonaparte at my house. Well, then, it is he who wishes to serve as father to my children. Do I love him? You are going to ask me. Well, no. DoT, then, find him unattractive? Again, no -- but worse still, I find myself in a state of indifference, of lukewarmness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bonaparte kitchen in Marseilles. Letizia is cutting vegetables with a knife, the sound of which allows a disapproving punctuation of her silences. The tap-tap-tapping of the knife dicing a carrot.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Mama, I'm sorry that I didn't write to you about this, but I thought that it would be much better to tell you myself. Tap, tap, tap.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Mama, I know that when you meet her, you will love her as much as I do. Tap, tap, tap.

dialogues.speaker: NOTE
dialogues.text: The following excerpts, from Napoleon's letters to Josephine will be read over the following scenes, which follow after the text of the letters. The visual will show Josephine's affair with Hippolyte Charles, and Napoleon's life in camp and on the march. The letters are presented uninterrupted by the scene descriptions, to preserve there flow.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dearest Josephine, every moment increases the distance between us, and with every moment that passes I feel myself less able to endure the separation. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAPOLEON (V.O.) (cont'd) You are the eternal object of my thoughts, and my imagination exhausts itself wondering what you are doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By what magic have you captivated all my faculties, concentrated in yourself all my existence? It is a kind of death, my darling, since there is no survival for me except in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask of you neither eternal love nor fidelity, but only truth, utter honesty. The day upon which you should say "I love you less," would be the last day of my love -- or the last day of my life. And if I should not die of sorrow, then, my heart, maimed for life, would never again trust itself to respond to any sentiments of tenderness or rapture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let many days go without writing to me. What, then, are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you write, dearest, assure me that you realize that I love you with a love that is beyond the limits of imagination. That you, you alone, and all of you, as I see you, as you are -- only you can please me, absorb the faculties of my soul; that there is no corner of my heart into which you do not see, no thought of mine which is not subordinate to you. That my arms, my strength, my mind are all yours. That my soul lives in your body. That the world is beautiful only because you inhabit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No letters from you -- only once every four days do I receive one, whereas if you loved me you would write me twice a day. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: * * * (cont'd) Absence relieves minor attachments but it intensifies love. A kiss upon your mouth, upon your heart, everywhere. There is no one else, no one but me, is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your letter is brief, sad and written in a trembling hand. What is wrong with you, my darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My misfortune is to have known you so little; yours, to have judged me by the men you have known, who surrounded you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have inspired in me a limitless passion, and an intoxication that is degrading. Josephine, you have made me wretched. But I have never believed in happiness. Is life really worth making such a fuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hours ago, there came that scrap of a letter to break the news that you are not coming, that you are ill, that there are three doctors in attendance, that you cannot write yourself. My life is now a perpetual nightmare. A fatal premonition stops me from breathing. I am ill of your illness, burning with your fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a month I have received only two notes of three lines each. Good God, tell me how you know so well how to inspire love in other's hearts, without feeling it in your own? Make mock of me, stay on in Paris, take lovers, let all the world know it, never write to me -- and then? And then, I shall love you ten times more than I did before!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't go on telling me that you are ill; (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: * * * (cont'd) don't go on trying to justify your behavior. You are forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your letters are as cold as friendship. What is left for you to do to make me more wretched? Stop loving me? That's already done. Hate me? Perhaps I should hope for that. Hatred, at least, is not humiliating. But, oh, indifference -- the pulse of marble, the vacant glance, the distracted air.

dialogues.speaker: NOTE
dialogues.text: Now the following scenes relate to the above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, seated at a table in his HQ tent late at night writing a letter by candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a bright, sunny morning in Josephine's bedroom at R de Chanterine. There is a letter from Napoleon leaning against the teapot on her breakfast tray. She picks up th envelope, sees who it is from, puts it down, pours her te adds milk and sugar, stirs it carefully, sighs, looks out at the tall trees rustling in the breeze, then idly picks the letter and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A close shot of Napoleon's hand, writing on his official stationary which has printed, under a large illustration symbolizing liberty and equality, "Headquarters of the Commander in Chief, Army of Italy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Le Clerc presents his aide, Captain Hippolyte Charles.  34.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL LE CLERC
dialogues.text: I should like you to meet my aide- de-camp, Captain Hippo Charles -- Madame Bonaparte.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CHARLES
dialogues.text: I am delighted to meet you, Madame Bonaparte.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Captain. Won't you both please sit down? Love at first sight.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL LE CLERC
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Madame Bonaparte. I have come at the instruction of General Bonaparte to bring this letter fro his mother in Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon lying awake in the early hours of the morning, i his camp bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlight. Josephine and Charles walk slowly in the garde They stop. She is still. He touches his lips to her shoulders and neck. She slowly turns, looks into his eyes and kisses him, long and languorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon standing at a camp fire in the rain, staring vacantly into the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josephine and Charles making love in her mirrored bedroom the Rue de Chanterine. Maximum erotica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spectacular shot of the French army on the march -- abo 5,000 men. Music.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Soldiers, you are half-naked and badly clothed. The authorities find much fault with you and yet can give nothing. Your patience, your courage are admirable but you are not getting any fame. I will lead you into the must fruitful plains in the world -- rich provinces and great cities shall be your possessions, and then you will have wealth, honor and fame in full measure.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Start of the lst Italian campaign.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: With the Italian campaign, Napoleon steps onto the stage as a figure of European importance. A dozen victories in as many months would be announced in dramatic and highly colored bulletins. The battles of the revolution had been so far mainly defensive. Now, there was revealed a new kind of offensive warfare such as had not been seen in Europe for centuries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army on the march -- a military band playing -- about 500 men.

dialogues.speaker: NOTE
dialogues.text: The following narration will be read over the following scenes.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon now introduced a new era of wars of maneuver. Everything would be sacrificed to mobility. The complicated battle formations of the century would be abandoned, and the army freed from clumsy baggage trains. War would be made to feed on war. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) The armies opposing him were still committed to the rigid ideas of the previous era, and their soldiers were treated as automatons. As they could not be trusted to forage for themselves without deserting, such armies were slowed down by their supply trains. The revolution, on the other hand, had produced an army of intelligent citizens, which could move fast by living off the country, and in which courage and initiative were rewarded by promotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small village in Italy. The advance guard cavalry scree about 100 troopers, gallop through the town and form a li preventing anyone from leaving in the direction of the en

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR
dialogues.text: Captain, take 20 men. Assemble all the inhabitants on the main street, and collect all mail and newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horse drawn artillery on the march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A party of 20 French infantry removing livestock and food a cart from a farmhouse. The farmer and his family look o in quiet despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A section on the march -- boy drummers, in their early te EXT. ITALIAN STREAM  DAY A big, exciting shot of about 200 cavalry crossing the stream.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the march -- an infantryman has a pet dog on a lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the march -- a soldier carries a parrot in a cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, on a horse, surrounded by his aides, studying a large map. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long shot of the opposing French and Austrian armies fa each other across the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There is no man more cautious than I am when planning a campaign. I exaggerate all the dangers, and all the disasters that might occur. I look quite serene to my staff, but I am like a woman in labor. Once I have made up my mind, everything is forgotten, except what leads to success. A cloud of sharp-shooters, some mounted, some on foot, advance to harass the enemy, escaping from his superior numbers, by their mobility, and from his cannon by their dispersal. Napoleon studies this exchange of fire to better understa the enemy's position. Surrounded by his entourage, he is a wooded platform constructed in the top branches of a la tree, overlooking the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The art of war is a simple art. Everything is in the execution. There is nothing vague in it. It is all common sense. Theory does not enter into it. The simplest moves are always the best.  38. When the French skirmishers finally reveal a chink in the enemy position, it becomes a focal point for the main eff Horse artillery are sent forward, on the gallop, to open with canister at close range. The main attacking force of infantry are then sent forwar moving up in columns and lines. The cavalry trots beside them, in the gaps, to make their presence felt where it will be best used. Drummers and bands fill the air with stirring music. Officers march smartly alongside their men. The precision of these attacking maneuvers is very import because the sight of the slow moving, perfectly aligned m of infantry is more frightening and discouraging to the defender than a wild bayonet charge. When the two main forces are about 100 yards apart, the Commanding Officer in the field starts the chant "Hymn to Victory" and places his hat, with its large tricolored cockade, on the point of his sword so that is can be seen all of his troops. When the distance narrows to about 50 yards, the defendin Austrians fire their first volleys -- first row, second r third row. The French fall everywhere, but the remainder fill in the formation and keep moving in regular step. This is the crucial point of the battle. The defenders no have to decide whether they are going to run or face the attackers' volley and subsequent bayonet charge. There is time for the defenders to reload. Now the French are 20 yards away and still hold their fir trained to do this because their psychological advantage lost once they have discharged their muskets. They want t defenders to break and run. Now panic has begun to set in and to dislodge the defendi Austrian troops. They start to give way. The French relentlessly move forward. The Austrian movements at the rear become a stampede. The officers signal with their swords, and the drummers b the charge. The sky rings with a thousand battle cries.  39. The cavalry dashes forward and hacks down the fleeing Austrian infantry, who are virtually helpless against the cavalry out in the open. The French have won the day, and their infantry fires the first volley at the backs of the fleeing Austrian troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The triumphal entrance of the French army into Milan. Wil enthusiastic crowds, floral arches, tricolors everywhere, glittering military bands, flags, columns upon columns of French troops, the smart clattering of the cavalry. Napoleon, on horseback, flanked by his staff and aides, h eyes shining, his expression transfixed, as if in a mysti reverie.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon would soon arouse the resentment of the Directory in Paris, exceeding his authority, making political decisions and treaties like a Roman Conqueror, enlarging his role to ruler of Italy. Only his tremendous success and ever increasing popularity prevented the Directory from replacing him.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: From that moment on, I foresaw what I might be. Already I felt the earth flee beneath me, as if I were being carried away up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Josephine are making love. Sunlight falling their bodies.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dear Therese, the journey here to Milan was the most difficult and uncomfortable imaginable -- I am bored to death. My husband doesn't love me, he worships me. I fear he will go mad with love. Worse than that, I fear for my poor Hippolyte. We may have been indiscreet on the journey, and I think Joseph and Junot suspect something.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderly announces Captain Hippolyte Charles. He is handsome, short and slight, very much in stature like Napoleon, and has a hairdresser's elegance. His behavior is absolutely correct during this interview, one could never infer any guilt on his part.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Come in, Captain Charles. Charles approaches the table and salutes smartly.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I believe you are acquainted with my brother, Joseph Bonaparte, and my aide, Major Junot.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I had the honor of meeting them on the trip from Paris. They nod, politely.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Captain Charles, I believe you are one of General Le Clerc's aides-de- camp.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I am.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Was it he who assigned you to command the escort which accompanied Madame Bonaparte's coach?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. There is a pause. Napoleon studies Charles.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Was the trip normal in every respect?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  Pause. 41.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Did any difficulties of any kind arise during the trip?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: No, sir, none at all.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Then, you have my thanks, Captain Charles, for safely escorting Madame Bonaparte to Milan, and you may consider your assignment completed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You will return to Paris tomorrow and you will carry my compliments and thanks to General Le Clerc for assigning such an excellent officer to carry out a responsibility which has meant so much to myself and to Madame Bonaparte.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. I will do that.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You may go, Captain Charles. Charles salutes and leaves. Napoleon sits and stares at h desk for several seconds, then he produces a letter from pocket and hands it to Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I would like both of you to read this. Please read it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) To Citizen General Bonaparte from one who does not wish to see him dishonored by his wife. You should know, Citizen General, that your wife has taken a lover, one Captain Hippolyte Charles... undated and unsigned. Joseph shakes his head. He hands it to Junot, who reads i and hands it back, looking to Joseph to speak first.  42.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Naturally, one does not take much stock in such a piece of filth but, on the other hand, it is not the sort of thing one can simply ignore. What do you think, Joseph?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Junot?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) No, one cannot simply ignore it.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I am afraid, then, I have to ask you both, Joseph as my brother, and Junot as my good friend, whether or not you know anything about this, or whether you saw anything at all during the trip which might make you suspect some truth to it. Joseph thinks for a moment and slowly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: No... nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Not even the slightest hint of something?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: No -- Captain Charles commanded the cavalry escort, and rode outside the carriage. In the evenings, he always ate at another table. They hardly ever spoke to each other.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You would tell me, Joseph, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, I would. You know I am not one of your wife's greatest admirers, but I certainly know nothing about this.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And you, Junot?  43.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No... No, I don't know anything about it either. Not a thing. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, thank you both. As I said, I shall regard this as a piece of malevolence from someone who does not wish well to myself or Josephine. Naturally, I shall trust to your discretion to say nothing about this. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, Eugene, Junot, Marmont and Murat, accompanied b large party of scientists, stand before the Sphinx.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On July 2, 1798, Napoleon arrived in Egypt with an army of 40,000 men, and a romantic dream of conquest, following Alexander's march into India. The Directory had been quick to approve his plan for attacking England, indirectly, through their Eastern Empire, rather than by invasion of Britain, and they breathed a sigh of relief to have their unemployed conqueror off the doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and the scientists inspect a mummy, brought out the sunlight, after thousands of years. A mood of somber reflection pervades the scene.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: There was an air of grandiose fantasy about the expedition. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) Napoleon took along a hundred and fifty distinguished scientists, intellectuals and artists equipped with libraries and scientific instruments. They would found the Institute of Egypt, do the preliminary survey work for the Suez canal, and unlock the key to hieroglyphic writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young drummer boy scribbles "Long Live the Republic" on face of some hieroglyphic writing. Several other soldiers closely scrutinize the ancient writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are inside of a French division square, defending itse against an attack of mameluke cavalry. Each side of the square is formed of three ranks of men, and artillery is placed at the corners. The inside of the square is about the size of a football field, and is virtually empty, except for a small group o officers surrounding Napoleon, and a fairly large group o terrified scientists and intellectuals, dressed in heavy European clothes, mounted on donkeys and camels, and carr umbrellas. Outside the square, the shrieking mamelukes recklessly charge, and are slaughtered by the disciplined and accura wall of French muskets. The scene will be shot only from inside the square, and f this vantage point, all we can see, over the heads of the defending French troops and clouds of dust, are the tops the mamelukes. Napoleon, pleased with the way things are going, rides ov to the groups of scientists, to cheer them up. He has to shout to be heard.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (shouting) Good afternoon, gentlemen. I hope you are enjoying this unusual spectacle. One cannot see this in Paris for any price. They are too frightened to be amused.  45.

dialogues.speaker: MONGE
dialogues.text: Are we doing well, General Bonaparte?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: We are doing very well, my dear Monge. The mameluke cavalry are brave but they are selling their lives at a bad price -- at a rate, I should say, of 50-1. My only fear is that Murad Bey has some means of communicating with his men, and that he will manage to call them off before we can kill a great many more. The artist, Denon, one of the stronger souls among the gr has been busy making sketches of the fighting. Napoleon r over to him and looks down at the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Those are excellent sketches, Denon. May I have them when you are finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captured mansion of Murad Bey, leader of the mameluke French-Arabian orgy -- quiet, cool, soft music, occasiona male voice, low female laugh; Murat, Marmont, Berthier, Monge. Not Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Napoleon is at work. He has taken over a large room, grouped several tables into an L-shape, and has made it i an office. He is seated before the usual 2-foot-high stac of dispatches, letters, memorandums and reports, which fo him everywhere. We hear the continuation of the music fro the previous scene. Napoleon, in an angry and irritable mood, is dictating to Bourrienne.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (dictating) Must you, too, take this opportunity during my absence to indulge the petty jealousies of the Bonaparte family? Must you... There is a knock at the door.  46.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Come in! Junot enters, extremely drunk.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I believe you sent for me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, please sit down. I will be with you in a moment. Junot staggers over to a couch and sits down heavily. Napoleon's glance lingers disapprovingly.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (to Bourrienne) Read it back.

dialogues.speaker: BOURRIENNE
dialogues.text: To Joseph Bonaparte -- Dear Joseph, I have been informed by my wife of the cold and spiteful treatment she has been receiving at the hands of my family, since my departure. I am also informed that you have refused to pay over to her any of the money I left with you expressly for this purpose. Must you, too, take this opportunity during my absence to indulge the petty jealousies of the Bonaparte family?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (quietly) Oh, shit, that's not right. He runs his hand through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Leave us alone, Bourrienne, and come back in half an hour. Bourrienne exits.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: God damn it, Junot, wouldn't you think I have enough things on my mind not to waste time on a letter like this to Joseph?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: (staring at his boots) There's probably some explanation.  47.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure he's been too busy chasing his whores to be bothered about my wife. Junot sits, breathing loudly.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, sorry to call you away from the festivities, but where is the breakdown on serviceable vehicles? I asked for it yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: (speech affected by drink) I gave it to Berthier... this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Why did you give it to him?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I thought he would be seeing you before I would, and would give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, he didn't give it to me, and when I ask you to do something for me, return the work to me, not to Berthier.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I thought he would give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I must have the breakdown now. Where is Berthier?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: He's downstairs -- somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: All right, thank you. Please ask him to come here. Junot pauses and then speaks with exaggerated importance earnestness brought on by too much drink.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Yes... but, first, can I say something to you, as a friend?  48.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I know that I shouldn't butt into things... that are really no concern of mine... but you shouldn't write a letter like that to Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Well, maybe he's only looking out for your best interests.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Nothing. That's all I can say.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: That's all you can say? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: That's all I can say.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Now, just a minute. You have just very clearly implied that there is a reason why Joseph should not give my wife the money which I left for her. I can't possibly allow a remark like that to go without explanation.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Let's just say, he looks after your interests. Napoleon takes Junot by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Look, Junot, you aren't going to leave this room until you explain yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: There are some things... better left unsaid.  49.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You mean about my wife?! You mean there are some things better left unsaid about Josephine?! Suddenly, Junot buries his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What the hell is the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: (mumbling into his hands) I didn't want to hurt you... All I wanted to do was to keep from hurting you. I swear I didn't want to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, whatever the hell you wanted to do, you are going to tell me everything right now. Do you understand?!

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: (pulling himself together) You know that... letter you showed me in Milan -- the one about Hippolyte Charles?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Yes, I wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I couldn't face telling you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You couldn't face telling me what?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: About Hippolyte Charles.  50.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What was there to tell?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: My God, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Do you know what you're saying?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: God help me -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: How do you know? Junot pulls himself together and speaks in an unnaturally controlled and somewhat mechanical way.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I was in her maid's room at an inn we stopped at for the night, outside of Dijon. It was an adjoining room to Madame Bonaparte's.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes? Junot searches for a better way to say it but doesn't com with anything.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I could hear them, in the next room. Napoleon's voice is barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You could hear them?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Yes. Napoleon stares at the corner of a table.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You mean you heard them making love?  51.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Yes. Napoleon sits down.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: How did you know it was Captain Charles?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I questioned the maid, and she admitted Charles had been Madame Bonaparte's lover for several months.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Can you give me a drink, please?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. What do you want? Napoleon stares into space and doesn't reply. Junot pours a glass of whisky. Napoleon drinks it down, distastefully.

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I wanted to kill him but Joseph convinced me it would be a mistake. He said people would say you hadn't the courage to deal with it yourself.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And was it so widely known that Joseph had reason for such concern?

dialogues.speaker: JUNOT
dialogues.text: I believe so. I believe Madame Bonaparte was not discreet, in Paris. A knock at the door. A momentary pause, then a much more urgent knock.

dialogues.speaker: BOURRIENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: General Bonaparte?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Come back in an hour.  52.

dialogues.speaker: BOURRIENNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, General Bonaparte, but I believe this is an extremely urgent matter, requiring your immediate attention.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Come in. Bourrienne enters.

dialogues.speaker: BOURRIENNE
dialogues.text: This dispatch has just arrived from Aboukir, marked highest priority, for General Bonaparte's eyes only.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Let me see it. He opens the envelope, reads it and tosses the note on th table.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (flatly) Nelson has engaged Brueys off Aboukir. Brueys is dead and we have lost eleven ships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wildly cheering crowds, flags, military band -- Napoleon rides in an open carriage, waving. He is followed by two other carriages, containing the small entourage, brought from Egypt. A beautiful floral Arc de Triomphe decorates end of the street.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On October 9th, 1799, Napoleon, with only a small entourage, arrived at the port of Frejus, in France, after a journey of six weeks, in which he evaded a large British fleet. The news of his arrival threw France into a delirium of joy. His return was seen as a kind of deliverance, by a nation in the grip of economic chaos, near anarchy and the threat of invasion.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room in Luxembourg Palace. Napoleon is seated bef the five Directors, Barras, Sieyes, Moulins, Gohier and R Ducos, who are dressed in their pompous official costumes with three-foot hats and feathered plumes. Present also a Talleyrand, Fouche, Joseph, Lucien and several dozen important officials.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Nelson's victory at Aboukir quite effectively finished the strategic purpose of the campaign, and with the loss of all our principal fighting ships, the army was marooned in Egypt, and our communications with the continent were severed. The only options remaining to me were to develop the occupation of Egypt, to maintain the morale of my army, and to respond to the threats being created by the English and, very soon, the Turks. This was accomplished, culminating in my final victory against the Turks, when they attempted a landing at Aboukir.

dialogues.speaker: GOHIER
dialogues.text: I wonder if you would care to tell us, General Bonaparte, why, so soon after this admirable victory, you decided to... abandon your army and return to France?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Citizen Gohier, my army was not abandoned -- it was left in a very strong position, and in the capable hands of General Kleber.

dialogues.speaker: GOHIER
dialogues.text: Of course, General Bonaparte. An unfortunate choice of words. Only the enemies of your glory, whom we shall regard as our own, would wish to give adverse interpretation to the honorable motives of patriotism, which I am sure, induced you to... leave... your colors. Please continue. Napoleon smiles, coldly.  54.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: After the defeat of the Turks, a negotiation to arrange the exchange of prisoners took place aboard Sir Sidney Smith's flagship. At the end of the first meeting, Sir Sidney gave my chief negotiator, General Marmont, several German newspapers, of a fairly recent date. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Now, you must bear in mind that for more than a year I had received no news at all from Europe, not a newspaper or a single mail packet. Perhaps you can imagine my state of mind when I read of the serious defeats that had been inflicted upon France during my absence: the loss of Italy, the Anglo-Russian army's occupation of Holland, the imminent invasion of France herself. After several days of deliberation, it seemed clear to me that it was my duty to risk the English blockade and, with a few small ships, attempt to return, to serve my country in any way that might be possible. Narration starts over Napoleon's dialogue which fades und

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The government of the Directory was bankrupt, and its presses ran all night printing the money it would spend the next day. Two of its five members, Sieyes and Roger- Ducos, who had the support of the moderate political factions, were preparing to seize power. They would welcome the inclusion of Napoleon who would secure the support of the army, and who was now the most popular figure in France.  55. The cutting of this scene will be done to place emphasis and establish a relationship between, two of the Director Sieyes and Roger-Ducos, Joseph Bonaparte, Talleyrand and Napoleon. Sieyes and Roger-Ducos will be cut with their names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Joseph driving through the park.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: The important thing is to find the right lawyer. One who will not protract the thing indefinitely, in the courts.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You know I am only too happy to be of help to you, but surely this isn't the ideal moment to involve yourself in such matters.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I know of no better time.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You can't be serious. It would not be good to become another husband out of a Moliere farce.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: The comedy of my marriage is sufficiently well known already.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: You must not act impetuously.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: It is time to clarify the situation. Everything is over between us.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: But you can do the same thing in six months. The next few weeks may be the most important ones in your life.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My mind is made up. She will not set foot in my house again. I think if I saw her again, I might be tempted to strangle her.  56. Joseph sighs and tries to think of another line of approa

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
