dialogues.text: Are you sure that you are not still in love with her?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Are you trying to insult me?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Of course not, but such violence of feeling makes me wonder.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, you shall see.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: When is she supposed to return?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Her maid said she left two days ago, to meet me -- I can imagine where she is. But when she finally does come home, she will find her things in the street and my door locked.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: She will probably appear with a dozen excuses and you will forgive her anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My dear Joseph, the only thing that is clear is that my wife is a slut - - and while a man may want a slut for his mistress, he does not want her for his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Josephine in bed. The mood is post-coital depression for Napoleon; submission and apprehension for Josephine. There is a long silence before any one speaks.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Were you in love with him?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: I thought I was. I was confused.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And now?  Pause. 57.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Now, I know that I shall die if you leave me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Do you expect me to believe that?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: And you, are you in love with any one else?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: But you have had mistresses while you were away.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Were you in love with any of them?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Were they pretty?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Were any of them prettier than I am?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: One had better legs.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Were any of them married?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes. They were the easiest. I made love to one of them within ten minutes of our first meeting.  58.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: She must have been in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Not in the least. After all, what is adultery -- only a brief transaction on a couch, requiring a few minutes of privacy. Josephine presses against him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Promise me you will never leave me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I cannot promise you that.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Promise me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I will never forgive you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: I don't care, but promise you will never leave me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I don't understand you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Promises mean nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Perhaps -- but tell me you promise, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: All right -- I promise.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: You are my old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small crowd of men talking to Napoleon, Sieyes, Roger- Ducos, Joseph and Lucien Bonaparte and Talleyrand. The meeting is jovial and relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: For the next three weeks, conspiracy was openly carried on in Paris -- in the salons of bankers, generals, politicians and government officials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fouche at work as Minister of Police.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The man responsible for protecting the government, the Minister of Police, Joseph Fouche, was part of the plot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sleepy deputy, in his night shirt, receives his special summons from a cloaked messenger.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In the early morning hours on November 9th, notifications of an emergency meeting of the councils, to be held that morning at 7 o'clock, were delivered to those deputies who supported the conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sieyes addresses the deputies. A good third of the seats empty.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Sieyes warned the sympathetic deputies of an imminent plot to seize the government by the radical Jacobin party, none of whose members had been summoned to the assembly. He then proposed two resolutions which were quickly passed.  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exciting clatter of horses hoofs on cobblestones draw confused spectators to the sight of Napoleon at the head 50 gold-braided generals, on their way to the assembly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The first called for the appointment of Napoleon to command the troops assigned to protect the councils. The second called for the councils to be moved, on the following day, to St. Cloud, ten miles from Paris, where they would be safe, and out of reach of the Paris mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barras, in his bathrobe signing 6 copies of his resignati Talleyrand hovers over him, carefully putting the signed copies to one side. Three officers stand by the door.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Later, the same day, the three members of the Directory who were not part of the plot were effectively taken out of the picture. Barras was forced to resign under threat of death and an offer of gilded exile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moulins and Gohier glumly eating an elegant lunch, laid o on a desk. Two soldiers stand guard at the door.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Gohier and Moulins, who would not be intimidated, were locked up under guard at the Luxembourg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warmly-dressed spectators have made the dawn journey from Paris, and are scattered about the gardens and lawns, breakfasting from picnic baskets. Groups of infantry laze on the grass, playing cards, read smoking and sleeping.  61.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The next morning, on November 10th, at the Palace of St. Cloud, the final moves were to be made which would bring Napoleon to supreme power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, narrow annexe, with high windows which open out o a courtyard, occupied by troops. There are no chairs and deputies, dressed in their strange-looking, long, scarlet togas and odd, square birettas, are uncomfortably crowded together, in emergency session. Lucien Bonaparte, who is the temporary President, looks worried. Delbrel, the leader of the Jacobin party is in the middle a speech to the deputies. He is an effective orator, with the right mixture of sarcasm and a sense of moral superiority.

dialogues.speaker: DELBREL
dialogues.text: Citizen Deputies, we have been isolated here at St. Cloud and surrounded by troops. Yesterday, we were told this was to protect us against a plot to seize the government. Today we are told that all five members of the Directory have suddenly, and without any warning, resigned. Now we have been asked to pass a resolution forming a provisional government, of three consuls to replace the five directors -- these three consuls being General Bonaparte and two of the newly-resigned members of the Directory, Sieyes and Roger- Ducos. We have further been asked to adjourn this assembly for a period of three months, leaving all executive and administrative power in the hands of the three newly- appointed consuls, who will then draw up a new Constitution. Angry murmurs.  62.

dialogues.speaker: DELBREL
dialogues.text: Citizen Deputies, does any one in this room have the slightest doubts as to what is being attempted, or to the identity of those who are involved? Angry murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: DELBREL
dialogues.text: Especially so, since I have it on excellent authority that the three members of the Directory who are not present here today have, indeed, not resigned willingly, but in the case of Gohier and Moulins, they are under arrest in the Luxembourg -- and, in the case of Barras, a resignation was forced from him under threat of death. Pandemonium breaks out in the assembly. Uproar.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN BONAPARTE
dialogues.text: (ringing bell) Order, order, order. Citizen Delbrel, you are out of order. You are out of order.

dialogues.speaker: DELBREL
dialogues.text: (shouting) And you, Citizen Bonaparte -- your role as President of this assembly is an honorary one, given only for the period on one month, on the occasion of your brother's return from Egypt. And since your nomination was originally put forward by the two conspirators, Sieyes and Roger-Ducos, I demand that you immediately disqualify yourself from these proceedings and leave this chamber!! Uproar of approval, and cries of "Long Live the Republic.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN BONAPARTE
dialogues.text: (ringing bell) You are out of order, Citizen Delbrel! You are out of order!  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conspirators wait in what was formerly one of Marie- Antoinette's reception salons, now bare of all furniture except three arm-chairs grouped before a large, ornate fireplace, in which there is a small fire. The shouting from the Orangery can be faintly heard throu the walls. Napoleon paces, nervously. Sieyes, huddled in an overcoat, stares apprehensively int the fire. Roger-Ducos pokes at it with a damp log. Joseph Bonaparte stands, gazing out of the window at the troops, sprawled on the grass. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Major Lavallette to see you, General.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Send him in. Lavallette comes in, salutes.

dialogues.speaker: LAVALLETTE
dialogues.text: General Bonaparte, I have a message from Lucien. He says there is not chance at all now to bring the proposals to a vote. Delbrel has given the alarm to the other parties. He says you must either use the troops immediately, or think of saving yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: SIEYES
dialogues.text: (to Napoleon) Oh, my God. I told you he should have been arrested yesterday. Why did I listen to you? Napoleon ignores Sieyes and walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Will you use the troops?  64.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Only as a last resort. What are the Councils doing now?

dialogues.speaker: LAVALLETTE
dialogues.text: Both chambers are swearing an oath to the Constitution. Knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: A message from Citizen Fouche.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Let me have it. The officer hands Napoleon an envelope and exits. Napoleo looks at the note and, then, reads it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My dear Bonaparte, if you have not already done so, I urge you to press things to a conclusion. I cannot guarantee the situation for very much longer in Paris. Sieyes, in an absolute panic, leans over and whispers to Roger-Ducos.

dialogues.speaker: SIEYES
dialogues.text: Go and make sure the carriage and driver are ready to leave at a moment's notice. Roger-Ducos exits. Napoleon paces the room.

dialogues.speaker: SIEYES
dialogues.text: Well -- what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Have patience -- all will be well. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Citizen Bourrienne to see you, sir.  He exits. 65.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Send him in.

dialogues.speaker: BOURRIENNE
dialogues.text: A message from Lucien -- he says that you had better act now. Delbrel is going to introduce a motion to halt the oaths and take a vote to outlaw the three of you.

dialogues.speaker: SIEYES
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! Oh, my God! We will all be on the guillotine in 24 hours.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Please stop chattering -- and let me think.

dialogues.speaker: SIEYES
dialogues.text: There is nothing left to think about. We will be outlawed! You've waited too long! I'm leaving, and any one who wishes to save his neck will follow suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputies going through the ritual of individually swearin their oaths to the Constitution. Napoleon enters with four grenadier guards and causes an immediate uproar. The grenadiers try to force a passage to approach the speaker's rostrum but a group of Jacobin deputies bar the way.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: What -- bayonets in here?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Soldiers! You are violating the sanctuary of the laws. Withdraw immediately!

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Please stand out of the way. Four grenadiers are no threat to you.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Withdraw! Withdraw!

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Citizen Deputies, please stand out of the way -- I wish to approach the speaker's rostrum!

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Is it for this, then, that you became a conqueror?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Withdraw, withdraw immediately, I say!

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Citizens, please stand aside. I wish to approach the speaker's rostrum.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Down with the Dictator! Down with the Tyrant!

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Outlaw him! Outlaw him! The cry is picked up of "Dictator," "Tyrant," and "Outlaw A scuffle breaks out and Napoleon is knocked to the groun and viciously kicked. His guards manage to club their way into this melee and drag him out of the Orangery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the soldiers, Napoleon, his face bloody, mounts a h and rides through his men. The troops are confused by his appearance but give him a cheer as he passes by. It is no five o'clock and the grey November dusk is closing in. A of "Long Live Bonaparte" thunders through the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deputies are still in an uproar, but gradually the so of drums, beating the charge, is heard. The drums get lou and a silence falls over the chamber. The drumming gets louder. The door is thrown open and Murat stands at the h of a column of grenadiers, with fixed bayonets.

dialogues.speaker: MURAT
dialogues.text: Citizens, you are dissolved.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputies climb through the windows and are jeered by the onlookers. Napoleon paces, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: At the age of 30, Napoleon would now become 1st Consul and head of the Executive, for a period of ten years. The other two Consuls would become merely figure-heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painted cardboard figures, about six inches high, representing Napoleon, Josephine and the principal person involved in the forthcoming coronation, are pushed about, discussed and noted, as the group plans the complex stage management of the coronation. Napoleon, Josephine, the painter David, and a small entou are seated, standing and kneeling around a cardboard mock of the interior of Notre Dame Cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In the five years that followed, Napoleon gave proof of his brilliant legislative, administrative and organizational powers. He created effective and enduring institutions of government; revitalized the economy; negotiated a concordat with the Pope, thus ending the religious rebellion in the Vendee; reconciled the bitterness between right and left by opening all careers to talent, and bringing into his government the best minds of the aristocracy and the ablest survivors of the revolution. Napoleon had secured the main social and material gains of the revolution, destroying privileged orders and modernizing the state. In exchange for this, he would now be given power far more absolute than any Bourbon monarch.  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coronation. At the moment when the Pope reaches for t crown of Charlemagne, to take it from the altar, Napoleon takes it, and, with his own hands, places it on his head. Napoleon looks, with an air of pride and satisfaction, at Josephine, as she advances towards him, at the altar, and when she kneels down, tears fall upon her clasped hands, raised to heaven -- or, rather to Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On December 2, 1804, Napoleon was made Emperor of France. He would later say: "I found the crown lying in the gutter and I picked it up."

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Duroc, I have a bill here for francs from Tirot, for building the Imperial throne and six decorated arm-chairs. The amount is absurd -- and, at least twice too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candlelight, silver service -- beautiful women, important guests. Napoleon and Josephine are seated at opposite end of a long table. Placed at Napoleon's elbow is the strikingly beautiful Madame Trillaud, a sexy brunette. He speaks to her husband. Dessert is being served.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: The revolution failed because the foundation of its political philosophy was in error. Its central dogma was the transference of original sin from man to society. It had the rosy vision that by nature man is good, and that he is only corrupted by an incorrectly organized society. Destroy the offending social institutions, tinker with the machine a bit, and you have Utopia - - presto! -- natural man back in all his goodness. Laugher at the table.  69.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: It's a very attractive idea but it simply isn't true. They had the whole thing backwards. Society is corrupt because man is corrupt -- because he is weak, selfish, hypocritical and greedy. And he is not made this way by society, he is born this way -- you can see it even in the youngest children. It's no good trying to build a better society on false assumptions -- authority's main job is to keep man from being at his worst and, thus, make life tolerable, for the greater number of people.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR TRILLAUD
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, you certainly have a very pessimistic view of human nature.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My dear Monsieur Trillaud, I am not paid for finding it better. Laughter. Napoleon exchanges a significant look with his Major-domo who nods, picks up a wine decanter, and comes up to Madam Trillaud's place to refill her glass, deliberately spilli wine on the front of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You clumsy fool. Quick, we need some water. Endless ad lib apologies by the Major-domo.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR-DOMO
dialogues.text: This way, if you please, Madame. The Major-domo gestures to some place out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No, no, I'll take care of it myself. We don't want to have any more accidents. Napoleon, the Major-domo and Madame Trillaud exit the roo amid apologies, reassurances. The guests resume their conversations, but Josephine, who seen the routine before, is distracted and agitated.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, hideaway room, reached by a back staircase, lead off Napoleon's private office. It is all couches, cushion velvet, mirrors and dim candles. Napoleon, Madame Trillaud and Major-domo enter.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Quick, where is the water?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR-DOMO
dialogues.text: Here it is, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ah, good, here -- allow me, Madame Trillaud. Napoleon and the Major-domo exchange another look, and th Major-domo hurriedly exits the room, springing a catchloc behind him. Napoleon's attention immediately shifts from Madame Trillaud's dress to Madame herself. His efforts to rub of the wine stains gradually become more intimate.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME TRILLAUD
dialogues.text: Oh! Your Majesty!

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid. Napoleon takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME TRILLAUD
dialogues.text: But the guests... my husband... the Empress...

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid, my dear. We shall be back before dessert is finished. Napoleon kisses her and fumbles with her clothes, to remo them. After several passionate seconds, there is a timid knock at the door. Madame Trillaud looks startled but Napoleon puts his fing to her lips and continues. After fifteen seconds, there is another knock on the door louder.  71.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (whispers) Don't worry. It's only the night maid. More kissing, then a louder and more insistent knock. Thi time they both sit up. More knocking. Madame Trillaud is frightened.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (angrily) Yes -- what is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Open the door. It's me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Go away -- I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know what you're doing in there.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous and go away -- I'm busy working.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where is Madame Trillaud?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: How should I know. Ask Roquier -- he's cleaning her dress.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing in there?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh -- now, this is absolutely ridiculous! If you don't want to be humiliated in front of your guests, you will return to the table at once.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Will you be joining us, soon?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I will be there in five minutes. Go back to your guests.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Five minutes.  72.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes!!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (weakly) Five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Madame Trillaud starts to get up. Napoleon stops her.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (whispering) Darling -- don't be ridiculous. We have five minutes. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MADAME TRILLAUD
dialogues.text: But, Your Majesty, we will be missed now.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Of course we won't -- five minutes will never be noticed. He tumbles her back on to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (in a subdued voice) How dare you do that to me tonight? How dare you? Do you realize who Madame Trillaud's husband is? Suppose he found out? Josephine sobs. Napoleon speaks in sharp hisses, to keep servants from overhearing.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up, will you? Josephine sobs.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Your tears have absolutely no effect on me... What a fool I have been! I am not a man like any other man. I must be free -- I must be free to do what I please. I must be free of this sordid jealousy!  73. Napoleon looks at the figure of his distraught wife. She on her knees, slumped across the seat of a chair.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (slowly and quietly) Very well, then, I will not put a specific time limit on this, but you must accept the idea that we will have to be divorced, and soon... And, from now on, we will sleep in separate bedrooms. This last remark finally causes Josephine to attempt to speak, red-eyed, sniveling, unable to put words together without involuntary shudders and sobs.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Separate bedrooms?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: But you will not... be safe...

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Not be safe? What on earth are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: (sobbing) In case of a... surprise attack... at night... I am such a... light sleeper... I could wake you... I could scream. This is such a pathetically dumb remark, it stops Napoleo cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, in his nightshirt, follow Roustam along the corridor. When they reach Josephine's door, Roustam hands Napoleon the candle and leaves. Napoleon knocks.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: It's me. Josephine quickly opens the door.  74.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Ooh! Napoleon enters the room and she locks the door. He walks the bed and sits down. He seems depressed. He sits, stari at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (touching the bed) Sit down. Josephine sits down next to him. He puts his arms around her, regretfully.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I didn't mean the things that I said... I was angry and I said more than I meant to.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh, my darling. I'm sorry, too. I won't do that again -- whatever you do. I won't cause you any more embarrassment, I promise. Napoleon squeezes her shoulder. Her surrender has not brought him happiness.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh -- I didn't tell you... I've seen Dr. Corvisart, and he was very reassuring and encouraging. He has had excellent results with the waters of Plombiers, and he thinks it would be a good idea for me to spend a few weeks there. Apparently, he sent Madame Le Floch there last year, and she gave birth to twins.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (laughs, weakly) Indeed -- well, you may tell Dr. Corvisart, I should be entirely satisfied with half her success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George III reviewing British troops. Military band. Spectators.  75.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Since the year 1069, France and England had been at war for a total of 152 years. And, from 1338, the Kings of England also called themselves the Kings of France, until Napoleon obliged them to drop this title at the time of the short- lived Peace Treaty of Amiens, in In the following year, England again declared war on France, and the conflict between British and French imperialism for maritime supremacy and world power would now be fought to a finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high, windy bluff, overlooking the English Channel. Napoleon and his entourage study the English fleet, moore several miles offshore, and the cliffs of Dover, just vis on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The struggle was resumed on familiar and inconclusive lines, as neither side could really get to grips, while England was supreme on the sea and Napoleon on land.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Showing French naval strategy.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon devised a plan to lure the British fleet into a wild goose chase, to the West Indies, leaving the Channel unprotected long enough for the French to ferry their army safely across. But the scheme was poorly executed, and eventually led to the disastrous French naval defeat at Trafalgar. EXT. OCEAN BOTTOM - DAY Eerie shot of two French ships lying on sea bottom.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drowned French Admiral floats in his cabin with his pap books, clothes and a roast chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francis II, the severe, opportunistic Emperor of Austria, reviewing his troops. He is a year older than Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon's invasion plans were foiled by England's correct naval strategy, and by their alliances with Austria and Russia. Subsidized by England, Francis II was goaded into war by Napoleon's assumption of the crown of Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 29-year old Tsar Alexander reviewing Russian troops.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He was joined by the young, melancholy Tsar Alexander I, who had ascended the throne at the age of after the Palace Guard murder of his father, Tsar Paul, and now had rival pretensions to Napoleon as the arbiter of Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young Tsar sits by the side of the road and weeps. Hi entourage stand by ineffectually, at a respectful distanc All around him is the evidence of the Russian disaster at Austerlitz.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But four months later, on the anniversary of Napoleon's coronation, Alexander would weep over the shattered wreck of his army, on the battlefield of Austerlitz.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold, blustery day. A large fire has been built at the base of a steep-sided gully. French cavalry vedettes are posted at the top of the hill. A party of 50 Austrian hussars, escorting 3 Imperial carriages, comes to a halt. Drummers and trumpeters sound a salute. Napoleon helps the defeated Emperor Francis, of Austria, his carriage, embracing him with cordiality. This is the first meeting between Napoleon and an importa European monarch.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear Francis, what a genuine pleasure it is to meet you at last.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I fear our meeting is long overdue... Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry that I am unable to offer you better hospitality, but this is the only place I have inhabited for the past month.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (shivering) You have made such excellent use of it; I should think you will hate to leave it.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Shall we move closer to the fire?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Yes -- an excellent idea. They leave their staffs standing on the road.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Will Alexander be joining us soon?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I very much doubt that he will.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I'm afraid he has been rather upset by the outcome of the battle.  78.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I see. Francis has developed a violent chill.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (shivering) But he asked me to say... (shivering) on his behalf... that your achievements have increased his... (shivering) admiration for you, and that he believes... your success is predestined by heaven... (shivering) and that his army...

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (interrupting) My dear Francis, you do seem extremely uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I am, just a bit.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (offering a flask) Would you like some brandy?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I'll have the fire built up. He shouts to his staff.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Berthier, we need some more wood for the fire -- and some brandy. Berthier issues orders and soldiers dash off for the wood aide dashes forward with the brandy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Francis, may I ask whether you wear warm winter underwear? Francis downs a big swig of brandy.  79.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (surprised) No -- not as a rule.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ah, well, that is the first rule of warfare. You must wear long- sleeved and long-legged underwear. You can never conjure up brilliancies with a cold bottom. They both laugh -- Francis, cheerlessly. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As an act of provocation, Prussian noble guards sharpen t swords on the steps of French Embassy in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Having ruined the Austro-Russian alliance by her neutrality, Prussia proceeded, in the following year, to commit suicide by taking on Napoleon single-handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen Louisa and King Wilhelm review Prussian troops.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Led by the warlike Queen Louisa, and her fashion-minded husband, King Frederich Wilhelm, the Prussians still believed themselves cast in the mold of Frederick the Great, and more than a match for Napoleon. The King had a special collection of 60 splendid uniforms, and was personally involved in the design of all the Prussian army uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If the French army had been commanded at Jena and Auerstadt by a tailor, the King of Prussia would certainly have gained the day.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon enjoying a performance of "Don Giovanni." An aid tiptoes into the box and hands him a note which reads: "Prussian ultimatum delivered to me today by Haugwitz. Wa is now imminent. Talleyrand." Napoleon quietly folds the note, putting it away in his pocket. Berthier leans over inquiringly. Napoleon puts hi finger to his lips, redirects his attention to the stage, crosses his arms and settles comfortably back into his se

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Prussia would make the same strategic error that Austria made in the previous year, and she would over-confidently rush forward to meet the French alone, without waiting for their Russian allies. In seven days of fighting, the Prussian army would be virtually destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsar Alexander, happy and confident, surrounded by aides, flags and military grandeur, on the march with his army.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Unconvinced by his defeat at Austerlitz, committed by alliance to Prussia and concerned about his interest in Poland, Alexander would once again take the field against Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colors of France and Russia flutter, side by side, in summer breeze, atop a large, ornately decorated raft, moo in mid-stream. It is an incredible sight, made of huge lo and planks, beautifully carpeted, draped with bunting, an with two small pavilions built on top, their roofs and wa covered with drapery, flags and colored silks. On the opposite banks are the massed formations and color the French and Russian Imperial Guards.  81. At a prearranged time, nervously checked and rechecked by pocket-watches, clicking open and closed, the two Emperor set off, in decorated long boats, to their rendezvous in stream. As they proceed, an unintentional race between oarsmen develops. Napoleon disembarks first and is thus able to welcome Tsa Alexander aboard. They embrace and, at this moment, a tumultuous roar of approval, the sound of fanfares, the beating of drums, is forth from both banks of the river. It is a splendid and marvelously absurd scene.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But in June of the following year, after the crushing defeat at Friedland, Alexander would be forced to sue for peace again -- this time in person, and with some surprising results.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear, Napoleon, how good it is to meet you at last.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And, what a great pleasure it is, indeed, to meet you, Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (looking around) And, what a delightful idea!

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ah -- you approve?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I think it's absolutely charming.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I'm glad you like it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Whatever suggested the idea to you?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (with exaggerated secrecy) I shall tell you in the strictest confidence -- when I was a boy, I had a passion for rafts, and never had the opportunity to build one.  82. They both laugh. The two Emperors now introduce their staffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Alexander, leaning on their elbows, on a lar map of the world, spread out on a table.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Alexander had come to treat as a fallen enemy, but would find that to be defeated by Napoleon seemed equivalent to winning a great victory. There would be not territorial demands, no reparations -- only an intoxicating proposal to divide the world between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Alexander slowly walk through the beautiful gloom of the dark forest. They are thoughtful, relaxed, enjoying the splendor of the late afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: We have no rivalry, we have no vital issues at stake. We are only at war because you are the ally of England, and, in this, it seems to me, you are serving only the interests of England. Alexander does not immediately reply.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (quietly and thoughtfully) If your fight is against England, and against her alone, then we shall easily come to terms -- for I have as much reason to complain as you have. England has brought me into conflict with false promises, and has left me to face defeat single- handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tsar and Napoleon riding together, their entourage an escort follow a few hundred yards behind.  83.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Alexander would spend two weeks together, seeing each other every day and sharing the entertainments of the evening. Each had set out to charm and flatter the other, and each would succeed. They would talk of everything together, as two brothers -- philosophy, women, politics, war, science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tsar and Napoleon seated together in a box at the theater.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dear sister, God has saved us. Instead of having sacrifices to make, we are coming out of this struggle with a kind of glory. But what do you think about this? I spend whole days with Bonaparte, and hours and hours in private conversation with him. I as you -- isn't this like something from a dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Alexander reviewing French troops.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If Alexander were a woman, I think I should fall passionately in love with him. But, at the same time, there is something very peculiar about him -- something lacking, but it is impossible to foresee precisely what will be lacking in any given instance, for the defect seems infinitely variable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander and Napoleon sit together, naked.  84.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You can always tell at a glance whether retreating infantry are being pursed by cavalry, because they hurry along and keep turning around and looking back. When they are retreating before infantry, they merely trudge along, head down.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Fascinating! Tell me, leaving aside the question of grand strategy, for the moment, what would you say is the single most difficult tactical skill to master?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Without a doubt, to estimate the enemy's strength on the battlefield. This is something that is only acquired by experience and instinct. At Jena, there were as many opinions about strength of the enemy as there were generals present. Murat said there were 50,000, preparing to attack. Berthier said there were no more than 25,000, about to withdraw. "Berthier sees only what is in the open," Murat said. "But don't forget there is a second force hidden in the forest." And so it would always go, each of them would judge things according to his own ability, character and state of mind, at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear Napoleon, sometimes I feel that I am not really an Emperor as you are.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I know absolutely nothing of war -- and I am still totally dependent upon my generals. Napoleon laughs, reassuringly.  85.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: That is a problem, and I can appreciate your feelings. But I'm sure you have great talent for war, and I could teach you a lot. If we are ever at war again together, you should lead, say, 30,000 men, under my orders -- you would soon get the feel of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon soaks in a steaming tub. Talleyrand, constantly wiping his glasses, balances on hi lap a thick sheaf of draft notes of the Treaty of Tilsit, referring to them during the discussion.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: Article 46, calls for the virtual dismemberment of Prussia, reducing her population by half and her army to a token force.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Does she deserve anything better?

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: Those are extremely harsh terms.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I did not ask her to go to war against me.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: Has Alexander agreed to this?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Yes, he has. Talleyrand looks dismayed and leafs through some more pap

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: Now, the section headed "Secret Clauses of the Treaty" -- Article provides for Alexander to serve as mediator between France and England and, if he fails to achieve a preliminary agreement within four months, it further provides that Russia is to go to war against England, and close her ports to English trade.  86.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: Do you think Alexander has any chance to succeed as a mediator?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I very seriously doubt it. I don't think there is any possibility of making peace with England so long as she sees herself safe from invasion. That is why we must increase the pressure on her economy. With Russia in the Continental Blockade, England must collapse. More than of her trade is with the Continent and Russia.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: England can make no move against you on the Continent without Austria. A reliable treaty with Austria would end her hopes in that regard.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: We have a treaty with Austria.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: Not one I should like to rely on. Francis is still smarting under the terms he had to accept after Austerlitz, and he is under great pressure to recover his losses.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My dear Talleyrand, none of the Kings of Europe bear any friendship for France. It is easy for you to talk of reliable treaties. The only treaties you have been able to negotiate are the ones I have won on the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: What I am talking about is moderation.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What you are talking about is a gamble on moderation -- when I gamble, I prefer to gamble on force.  87.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: And where do you place Alexander?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Alexander and I are friends. We have reached an understanding.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: I hope that understanding is worth as much as you think it is, sire. My impression of Alexander is that he is moody and impressionable, capable of acting on sudden impulses which then lead to sudden embarrassments. He is an unpredictable mixture of idealism and vanity. You have dazzled him, and you have performed a diplomatic miracle, but Alexander is weak and he is easily influenced by the last one who has his ear.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: That is a matter of opinion.

dialogues.speaker: TALLEYRAND
dialogues.text: Sire, you have only enemies in the court of St. Petersburg, and I fear outside your influence, Alexander will have another look at what he has agreed to.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: He will stand by his agreement -- I know him better than you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Alexander exchange fraternal embraces, on th bank of the Niemen river. Music, cheers, massed troops, flags, cannon salutes.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (embracing Alexander) My dear Alexander, between us there must never be any third parties. We must always deal directly with each other and never allow Ministers or advisors to muddy the waters.  88. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present for the Imperial divorce are all the high officer the Crown and the Empire, the Bonaparte family, Hortense, Eugene. Josephine is seated next to Napoleon, her eyes downcast.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: The political interests of my monarchy, and the wishes of my people, require that I should transmit to an heir, the throne, on which providence has placed me. For many years, I have lost all hopes of having children by my beloved wife, the Empress Josephine. It is this consideration which induces me to sacrifice the dearest affections of my heart, to consult only the good of my subjects, and to desire the dissolution of our marriage. Josephine, holding a paper in her hands, tries to read it uncontrollable sobs choke her voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: With the permission of my august and dear husband, I must declare that, retaining no hope of having children, who may satisfy the requirements of his policy in the interests of France, I have the pleasure of giving him the greatest proof of attachment and devotedness that was ever given on earth... She cannot continue, and breaks down completely. Eugene a Hortense comfort her. Hortense is crying, too. But the Bonaparte family watch the proceedings, unmoved. have never forgiven Josephine.  89. Napoleon is pale and shaken. He whispers to an official, Regnault de Saint-Jean-d'Angely, who picks up Josephine's speech from the floor. He reads the speech to the accompaniment of Josephine's tears.

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELY
dialogues.text: I respond to all the sentiments of the Emperor in consenting to the dissolution of a marriage which is now an obstacle to the happiness of France, be depriving it of the blessing of being, one day, governed by the descendants of that great man, who was evidently raised up by providence to efface the evils of a terrible revolution, and to restore the altar, the throne and social order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Josephine walking, arm in arm. Their entoura follow, a few hundred feet behind.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On the day after the divorce, Napoleon drove to Malmaison to visit with Josephine, and this visit was to set a pattern for all those to come. They were always announced in advance, there was something ceremonious and constrained about them, and they always left Josephine in a state of deep depression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room at Malmaison. Josephine and Hortense are dinner. Josephine is reading a letter from Napoleon, her food untouched. Hortense is nervous and upset.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: (reading from letter) My dearest Josephine -- I was heartsick at the sight of you yesterday. I, too, am sad today and need to know that you are more composed. This great palace echoes with emptiness and I feel terribly isolated. I am dinning all alone tonight. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEPHINE (cont'd) The page I sent to Malmaison this morning tells me he saw you weeping. You promised me you would stop. I want very much to come to see you but you will have to show more self-control. Josephine puts the letter down.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: (vacantly) Sometimes I have the feeling that I am dead, and that the only sign of life remaining to me is the vague sensation that I no longer exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon is dancing with Murat. The only other person in large ballroom is Berthier. A trio of musicians, placed outside the closed door, plays a waltz. Murat is teaching Napoleon how to waltz. He is an expert teacher, and Napoleon is a reasonable pupil. Berthier watches glumly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duroc is dozing in an arm-chair. He is awakened by the arrival of the Austrian Ambassador, Schwarzenburg, who en the room, covered with mud, his face smeared with blood, a deep cut behind his ear, trickling blood down on his collar.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: Good heavens, Ambassador -- what has happened?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
dialogues.text: Ah, good evening, my dear Duroc. I'm afraid I've been out hunting and I have had a rather bad fall.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: Indeed you have, Ambassador. Have you sent for a doctor?  gl.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
dialogues.text: Yes, I have, and I hope you will forgive me, Duroc, but unless your visit is extremely urgent, I shall have to ask you to excuse me until tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: I beg your indulgence, Ambassador, but it is.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
dialogues.text: (holding his face) Oh? He takes the Ambassador by the elbow and speaks softly so that they cannot be overheard.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: The Emperor has decided to marry your Archduchess, Marie-Louise.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: Earlier this afternoon, the Emperor refused the hand of the Grand Duchess Anna, of Russia, and, as I'm sure you can appreciate, he is quite able to change his mind again. For the Emperor, to choose a wife, is only a matter of minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
dialogues.text: But this is not a matter which can be settled tonight, surely?

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: No one can say how the Emperor's thoughts work, Ambassador, and unless we move quickly, he might change his mind again.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARZENBURG
dialogues.text: But, my dear Duroc, how can I act without guidance from Vienna? I haven't the slightest idea of how the Emperor Francis might feel about this.  92.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: May I suggest that we can prepare and sign the agreement, between ourselves, subject to the approval of the two Emperors. Believe me, my dear friend, your Archduchess, Marie-Louis, may very well hold, in her hands, the future of our two countries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The proxy wedding of Marie-Louis and Napoleon in Vienna. Archduke Charles stands in for the absent Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS II
dialogues.text: I grant my daughter's hand to the Emperor of the French.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: I, with my father's permission, give my consent to my union with the Emperor Napoleon. Berthier turns to Marie-Louise, presents her with a lette from Napoleon, and a portrait of him, in a medallion, surrounded by 12 extremely large diamonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie-Louise's coach, and those of her entourage bounce a a road near Compiegne, in a driving rain storm. Napoleon's sister, Caroline, Queen of Naples, reviews the protocol to be followed. Marie-Louise looks tired, confused, slightly sick and anxious.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: (reading) On arriving, the Empress Marie- Louise will ascend the steps on the north side, and the Emperor Napoleon will use those on the south side. The monarchs will arrive at the middle simultaneously. Upon perceiving the Emperor, the Empress will kneel and bow her head, and the Emperor will raise and embrace her.  93. Suddenly, there is a banging on the windowpane, and the w shriek. The door opens, and a man, on horseback, jumps in. Marie-Louis is seized, passionately embraced and drenched a rain-soaked cloak. Shrieks and laughter.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (laughing) Good evening, ladies. You must forgive me, my dearest wife, but I simply could not wait to see you.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: Oh, then you are...

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yes, my dearest Marie-Louise, I am your husband. They both laugh. Napoleon looks at her, admiringly, and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My dear, sweet Marie-Louis, you are even more beautiful than your portrait. Marie-Louise giggles and lowers her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: And, where did you see my portrait?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ah, you must forgive me, my dearest Marie-Louise, I saw it during one of my stays at your palace -- at Schonbrunn. They both laugh. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (jokingly) I hope you will forgive me for any inconveniences I may have caused you, and your family, in the past.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And, you, my dear wife, do you find that I resemble my portraits?  94.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: You are much younger, and much more handsome, than your pictures. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Good! Good! Then we are both pleased with each other. How fortunate we are -- eh? How fortunate we are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and Marie-Louise in bed, the marriage is about t consummated. Her cloistered upbringing has not prepared h very well for this moment. Each time Napoleon is about to take her in his arms, she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: Do you like music?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (gently) Yes, I do -- very much.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: Will I be able to play the harp? It is an instrument of which I am very fond.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Of course, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: You are so good to me. Will you also allow me to have a botanical garden?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: You may have anything you wish, my sweet and lovely Marie-Louise.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: I am told that Fontainebleau has many lovely views. I know nothing more interesting than a lovely countryside.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I am sure you will enjoy the French countryside.  95.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: I hope you have patience with me. I do not know how to dance the quadrille but, if you desire it, I will learn.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I only desire what gives you pleasure, my dearest.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: Will it be possible to have my dog, Bijou, sent here? I was not allowed to bring her and I love her so much.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Of course, my dear -- how cruel to have been separated from her. And how strange it must be for you to be here, away from your family and everything you know.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I am very happy. But you must have patience with me... I know nothing at all of what a wife must know. And I know nothing about men. My papa has never allowed me even to have a pet of the male gender.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Did the Emperor or Empress give you any... instructions of any kind... before you left?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: Papa said only to comply with any request you might make of me.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh, my dearest child -- you must not worry about anything. I will teach you everything that you must know. Napoleon sits up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Do you know the joke about the two Swiss boys who go to a bordello for the first time?  96.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: (giggles) No.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, two nice little Swiss boys, who are virgins, decide they will save up their money and go to a bordello. Marie-Louise giggles.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: At the door, one of them loses his nerve and decides to wait in the street while his more adventuresome friend goes inside. Fifteen minutes later his friend comes out. Napoleon does the dialogue with a heavy Swiss accent.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: "Well, what was it like?" the timid one asks. "Oh," his friend nonchalantly replied, "The movements are ridiculously simple, but the feeling is wonderful!" Marie-Louise shrieks with laughter which persists until t run down her cheeks. Napoleon gently takes her into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
dialogues.text: (trembling) Blow out the candle, please. He does. The screen is black. We hear some heavy breathin then Marie-Louise, giggling -- then, themes and variation her giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon holds up his son, the infant King of Rome, to th cheering multitude below. Standing beside him are Marie- Louise, his mother and entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josephine is showing the year-old, King of Rome, the smal Malmaison zoo. She carries him in her arms.  97. Madame de Montesquiou, a kind woman, the child's governes walks along with them.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: (wistfully) Ah, my dear Madame de Montesquiou, you have no idea what happiness it brings me to see this child, at last. I was told the very idea of such a visit would too much distress the Empress.

dialogues.speaker: MONTESQUIOU
dialogues.text: I am delighted to be of service to you again, Your Highness. And I can tell you, my instructions came directly from the Emperor, with a caution to be discreet.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh... I see. I understand. How is... the Emperor?

dialogues.speaker: MONTESQUIOU
dialogues.text: I rarely see him, Your Highness, but I believe he is in excellent health, and he is very happy with the child.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Ah, that is good.

dialogues.speaker: MONTESQUIOU
dialogues.text: And, you seem in excellent health, Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Ah, well, my dear Madame de Montesquiou, peace of mind can eventually be a substitute for happiness. Suddenly, the little boy begins making happy noises about of the animals, and Josephine hugs him. Her eyes fill wit tears.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: My dear sweet child, one day, perhaps you will know the sacrifice I have made for you, and I leave it to your governess to make you aware of it.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imperial Guard sergeant proudly carries the King of Rome. Napoleon and Marie-Louise are seated on a park bench near

dialogues.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My adorable papa, I can announce to you that your prophesy has been realized. I am as happy as possible. My husband loves me profoundly and I return his affection. I feel sure that I shall live happily with him. I assure you, my dear papa, that the Emperor is as careful of my health as you would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King of Rome, now 1 1/2 years-old, riding in a magnificen decorated cart, pulled by two lambs, supervised by Napole Marie-Louise, Duroc and Murat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King of Rome is asleep, holding onto one of Napoleon' fingers. Letizia looks lovingly at her son and grandson. Magnificent toys are scattered about the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow, sandy track. A French courier, Major Fidon, in heavy barouche, is making slow progress. Immediately behi him is a Russian light kibitka, which has, for some time, been unsuccessfully trying to pass him. The driver of the Russian vehicle is impatiently ringing a bell and cursing

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
dialogues.text: (taps on the window) Stop the carriage! The French driver brings the horses to a sudden halt, alm causing a collision from the rear. The French courier storms out and hurries to the Russian carriage. Ignoring the driver, he unceremoniously opens t door and addresses a very distinguished looking Russian gentleman seated inside.  99.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
dialogues.text: (bristling with anger) Good day, monsieur. Do you think it is possible for you to tell your driver to stop ringing that bell?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: My regrets, my dear Major, but I believe you have been blocking the road.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
dialogues.text: Are you trying to provoke me, monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: No, Major, I merely wish to state that your vehicle appears to be somewhat slower and heavier than mine, and point out that, if you would be kind enough to pull over to one side of the road, I could pass you and be on my way.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
dialogues.text: May I inform you, monsieur, that I am Major Fidon, official courier to the court of the Emperor Napoleon, on my way to our Embassy at St. Petersburg and, in accordance with the rules of the road, no one may overtake or pass me.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Before you quote the rules of the road to me, Major, may I point out to you that you are not in France now, but that you are a guest in Russia.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
dialogues.text: If I have given you any cause to be insulted, monsieur, may I offer you immediate satisfaction?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: (pulling his door closed) If you wish to put things on that basis, then I will say good day to you, monsieur. The French officer glares at him and walks back to his carriage. He gets back inside and drives off, still block the road.  100. Suddenly, the road widens and it becomes possible for the Russian to pass. The driver seizes the opportunity and easily passes the French barouche.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
dialogues.text: (shouting) Insolent bastard! Insolent bastard! In a fury, the French courier pulls out his pistol, leans of the window and fires several poorly-aimed shots at the rapidly diminishing vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: By 1810, relations between France and Russia were wearing thin. The terms Russia had agreed to at Tilsit, three years earlier, were proving to be unrealistic and ruinous to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsar Alexander and Caulaincourt. Alexander is slightly drunk.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It is a thing entirely unknown in diplomacy, that one government should assume a right to dictate to another, who is upon terms of equality, the conditions on which she should conduct her commerce; and, assuming such a right, second it by threatening language, in case of non-compliance.

dialogues.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
dialogues.text: But, Your Majesty, the very substance of the Tilsit treaty was that you should join the Continental Blockade, boycott English goods, suspend all commercial dealings with her, and be France's ally. Nothing more is being asked than to comply with the treaty.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: My dear Caulaincourt, agreements can endure only when they allow both sides to live. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEXANDER (cont'd) Napoleon may believe it is necessary to injure England but, before that, he must realize it is necessary for him to allow his friends to live. He cannot expect me to tell my nobles they must ruin themselves so that he can bring England to her knees -- and I'm afraid that is what it has come to.

dialogues.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
dialogues.text: I can appreciate what Your Majesty is saying but the Emperor has staked everything on this policy. He has no other way to attack England, and no one knows more than Your Majesty how his overtures for peace have been rejected.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It's a fine thing to establish policies but, when they don't work, they must be reconsidered. Granted that you have hurt England, but she is still on her feet. And to seal off her trade with Europe, what has it cost you? You have had to rule with an iron hand. You have turned friends into enemies. And even at that, the result has only been partly effective. You have never been able to stop the extensive cheating, smuggling and corruption - - even of your own officials. But I should think the situation in Spain, alone, would give your policy a minus balance. You have had to commit a quarter of a million of your best troops against the guerrillas, with no victory in sight. And you have given England a dangerous foothold on the Continent, for her armies.

dialogues.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
dialogues.text: I am in no position to debate this with you, Your Majesty, but can you imagine what a blow it will be to the Emperor if you should now desert his cause? It would mean nothing less than victory for England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Caulaincourt, you have no idea of how compromised my own position has become since Tilsit. I am blamed by the army for the military disaster at Austerlitz and Friedland, by the nobility for ruining their trade with England, by the merchants who must accept French foods at unprofitable prices, and by the nation for allowing Napoleon to dictate Russian policy. Alexander comes up to Caulaincourt and takes his arm. speaks slowly and factually.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Caulaincourt, my father was strangled in his bed by his own Palace Guard. Can you blame me for not wishing to meet the same end? Caulaincourt is at a loss for a reply.

dialogues.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
dialogues.text: Your Majesty knows my affection for him is deep and genuine, and goes far beyond my official role as Ambassador. But I would be remiss in my feelings for you, and in my responsibility to the Emperor, if I did not say that it is entirely possible that the Emperor will view your refutation of the terms of the Treaty of Tilsit, as the first step in the exchange of a French alliance for an English one -- with all the dangers that might entail.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (after a long pause) I have given a great deal of thought to that possibility, and I am prepared to face it. If it should come to war, and I presume that is what you are alluding to, I would rather have war with the Emperor than my own people. 102. He  103.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Monsieur Barbier, I would like to have all the books, that are best worth consulting, on the topography of Russia, and especially of Lithuania, with special attention to the rivers, forests, roads, marshes and so forth. I would also like to have the most detailed account there is of Charles XII's campaigns in Poland and Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maps and books are everywhere. Napoleon is on his hands a knees, creeping around on a huge map of Russia.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The seeds of the Russian campaign of were planted at Tilsit, in and began to bear fruit in when Alexander reopened his ports to British goods and imposed high tariffs on French imports. From then on, the situation between France and Russia steadily began to deteriorate -- friction grew, accusations were exchanged, spasmodic negotiations were attempted, tension increased and extensive military preparations were carried out by both sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowds. Honor Guard. Imperial carriages. Napoleon and Marie-Louise greet Francis of Austria, Frederich Wilhelm Prussia, and the other Kings.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon had made up his mind that a showdown with Russia was inevitable. Dresden was appointed as a mutual rendezvous for all the Kings, Princes, Dukes and dependent royalties of every description, who were subordinates to Napoleon, or who hoped for good or evil at his hands. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) And it was here, on May 16, where for the last time he would appear as King of Kings. Emperor Francis of Austria and his wife, Maria Ludovica, embrace the Imperial couple.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (embracing Francis) Since my marriage, some people have said the lion has been sleeping -- they will now see whether he has been sleeping. Good-natured laughter.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The Emperor of Austria, with his Empress, had come to honor his mighty son-in-law. But he had already written to Alexander that the Treaty just signed with France should not, he hoped, prevent Russia and Austria from continuing their secret understanding, relative to their common political views. King Frederich Wilhelm embracing them.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The King of Prussia also came to pay his respects. He had already written to Alexander, excusing himself for having yielded to irresistible force and fatality. "If war breaks out, we shall harm each other only as much as is strictly necessary, remembering constantly that we are one, that we must one day be allies again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and the monarchs are seated at a large table.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Never was the success of an expedition more certain. I see on all sides nothing but probabilities in my favor. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAPOLEON (cont'd) For the first time, I advance at the head of the combined forces of France, Austria, Italy, Germany, the Confederation of the Rhine, and Poland. He smiles at each ruler as their country is mentioned.

dialogues.speaker: EMPEROR FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Let us hope that just the sight of our preparations will cause Alexander to yield.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: That is my fervent hope. I love Alexander, as a brother, and wish him no harm.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICH WILHELM
dialogues.text: If war should come, Alexander has sworn he will not make peace under any conditions, however many battles he may lose, using the size of his country, the poverty of the soil and the rigors of the climate, to wear you down.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I know he has said that, and I am sure that he would like to believe it's true. But Russia is a semi- Asiatic nation which cannot field an army as large as your own, and has no literature or music to speak of. It is a barbarian nation, and barbarians are superstitious and have simple ideas. A single blow delivered at the heart of the Russian Empire, at Moscow the Great, Moscow the Holy, will, ina single instant, put this whole blind apathetic mass into despair. Napoleon pauses, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I know Alexander. His imagination must be struck by some great, bold, powerful stroke, and he will come back to me, just as he did at Friedland.  106.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: With his army of 400,000 men in concealed bivouacs, on a ten mile front, in the forests, bordering the banks of the Vistula river, Napoleon conducted a last minute personal reconnaissance, disguised in the uniform of a Polish lancer. Napoleon rides along the river bank, accompanied by Berth Murat, Duroc, Bessieres and Davout, all similarly disguis The opposite bank of the river is silent and deserted. Th only sounds to be heard are those of the river and of bir singing. Suddenly, Napoleon's horse stumbles and falls. Napoleon i stunned and helped to his feet by his concerned entourage

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (smiling) Well, this is an ill-omen, indeed. Caesar would probably turn back. There is uneasy laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive shot of the Grand Army on the march. Maximum numbers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The campaign of 1812 was the first time in which Napoleon had a marked superiority of numbers, but in accumulating such a mass of uneven quality, he would defeat his object, which was to bring about another Austerlitz or Friedland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russian army retreating in good order.  107.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The disparity of numbers left the Russians no option but to avoid battle and repeatedly disengage, however much political pressure developed for them to stand and fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russian rear guard cavalry setting light to the deserted houses.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Alexander gave orders that his retiring army should blow up bridges behind them, destroy the cities and villages, remove all the necessities of life, and leave behind them, nothing but a desert waste.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Although the Russians refused any major encounters, there was fierce fighting between the French advance guard and the Russian rear guard. Concealed in some trees, the Russian rear guard cavalry occupies a height, above a village occupied by the French advance guard infantry. Fifty French grenadiers, part of the advance guard, ascen the hill, unaware of the enemy cavalry waiting for them. When the French infantry are half way up the hill, the Russian cuirassiers and cossacks gallop down the hill and surround the grenadiers, who immediately form into a squa It is no contest. 200 cavalry against 50 infantry, with n help in sight. The Russian officer commanding the cavalry rides up to th demanding their surrender. The officer, in command of the French, answers by killing him with a pistol shot. Upon t the Russian cavalry, inexplicably, leave the field, allow the French to withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing progress of the Grand Army's march through Russia during the summer of 1812. Narration to explain situation.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The Tsar's scorched earth strategy was in line with the views of some of the more enlightened Russian strategists, but the army and the people were full of reckless confidence and impatience for battle, and the long retreat to Moscow filled them with bitterness and a sense of feebleness and incompetence at the top.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: As Napoleon approached Moscow, the court of St. Petersburg was in despair, and the Tsar, his resolve shaken, was ready to sue for peace. Now, the intervention of one man, Count Feodor Vasilievitch Rostopchin, the Governor of Moscow, would have a decisive effect on the course of history. 108. Rostopchin is a steady man, a good husband and father -- man of gentle and attractive manners, with a superior and cultivated mind. Present are the head of the secret polic and eleven senior Moscow officials. The doors are locked, the shades are down and the men speak in low voices.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTOPCHIN
dialogues.text: My friends, I have it now on excellent authority that the French will enter Moscow within a few days. Kutusov still swears he will fight to the death, but I have learned, on excellent authority, he has plans to surrender the city without a struggle. Our empire is almost overthrown. The court of St. Petersburg trembles, and will begin peace negotiations as soon as Napoleon enters the Kremlin. One can only imagine what will be lost. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSTOPCHIN (cont'd) My friends, we are living in a time when men of conviction must be prepared to influence the nation even without the approval of their sovereign. They must dare to evaluate the public and private interests which they may be called upon a sacrifice. He looks around the group.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTOPCHIN
dialogues.text: The flames of our beloved Moscow will erect a barrier of fire between the Tsar and all weakness, and they will rob from Napoleon the end and the aim of his campaign. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTOPCHIN
dialogues.text: Is there anyone who wishes to withdraw? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTOPCHIN
dialogues.text: Very well -- there is a great deal to be organized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon standing on the summit of Sparrow Hill, looking the glittering domes and minarets of Moscow, in the dista Moscow is lordly and striking, with the steeples of its 3 churches, and its copper domes glittering in the sun; its palaces of eastern architecture mingled with trees and surrounded with gardens; and its Kremlin, a huge triangul mass of towers, something between a palace and a castle. But not a chimney sends up smoke, not a man appears on th battlements or at the gates. All is silence. His marshals are gathered around him.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: It was all very well for Alexander to do more damage to his country than I could possibly do, but he could not destroy Moscow. This is the prize that will end the war. You will see, we will have peace offerings from him within a few days.  110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A French cavalry patrol finds Moscow a ghost-town, desert lifeless, a city of the dead, except for the eerie echo o their horses' hoofs. Behind them, a column of a 100 infantry march, led by a drummer and a drum-major. Suddenly, a wild-looking man, with long grey hair down to shoulders, and a thick white beard, armed with a pitchfor rushes out of an alley and into the path of the troops. He is such an incredible sight, the men laugh at him.

dialogues.speaker: DRUM-MAJOR
dialogues.text: Hello, grandfather. Are you the only welcome we shall have today? More laughter. The old man suddenly attacks the drum-major with the pitchfork, which the unfortunate man takes full in the be letting out a horrible scream. Several soldiers rush up to the old man and drag him off. An officer shouts to bayonet him. A soldier stabs at him but finds his bayonet will not penetrate the man's thick sheepskin coat. Several others have the same result. The officer rides up and, without further ado, shoot him his pistol, accidentally wounding a French soldier in the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon is sleeping heavily. Duroc and Caulaincourt stan over him, gently trying to wake him.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What do you want? Napoleon immediately becomes aware of the strange light i the room, leaps out of bed and rushes to the window. The entire city seems to be in flames.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My God...! What time is it?  111.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: Four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My God, what a fire! They stand in silence.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: When did it start?

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
