dialogues.text: The first reports came in at about ten.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Why didn't you wake me then?

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: At first, it hardly seemed more than a routine fire.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: How did it spread so quickly?

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: It is the work of incendiaries.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I told Mortier that he would answer with his life for any looting.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: Our troops have no part in this. It has been started by the Russians!

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Impossible, I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: We have already captured a dozen incendiaries, convicts, released just two days ago. They said they were acting under orders of the secret police.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: But to start a fire like this in five hours -- how is it possible? It would take a carefully organized plan, tons of combustibles and hundreds of people.  112.

dialogues.speaker: DUROC
dialogues.text: From what we can tell, there are hundreds of agents, all over the city. The combustibles seem to have been carefully placed beforehand, and all the fire- engines have been removed from the city.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My God -- this could be very bad for us... very bad, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fires are started by wild-looking men and women in rags, wandering about in the flames. An official of the secret police gives orders and carefully writes something in a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three Russians, one of whom is armed with a lance, the se with a sword, the third a lighted torch, are setting fire a house. A party of 5, unarmed, French soldiers, dragging a cart containing loot, surprises them. The Russian with the lance puts himself in a position of defense. The others simply ignore the French and continue about their work. One of the Frenchmen grabs a long pole from a smoldering carriage, using it as a quarterstaff, and attacks the man armed with the lance; he quickly breaks both his legs and Russian falls with a terrible cry of pain. The Frenchman strikes him on the head killing him. The other two Russians run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some French soldiers making jam fritters in the smolderin ruins of a bakery while the fire rages at the other end o the street, and furniture, sliding down from collapsing floors, crashes to the pavement.  113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander is in bed with a heavy cold, and in a foul mood

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: I hope you will forgive me, Your Majesty, for requesting an audience at such a late hour, but I have traveled all the way from Moscow to see you, on a matter which cannot wait.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Very well, General, what is it you wish to say?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, I have been advised that you have received a letter from Napoleon, offering a peace treaty, and that you have decided to accept it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I have decided to accept the principle of a negotiation; the terms are not established.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: If I may, Your Majesty, I would like to offer a dissenting opinion.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: General Kutusov, feel free to say whatever you like.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: I believe I am right in saying that, before the fire, the country had grown weary of the war, and there were few who were interested in continuing the battle.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: But, since the fire, a completely new spirit has been aroused in the nation. The French have become an army of criminals, against whom Russia must be avenged, against whom she is now prepared to fight to the death.  114.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You know, General Kutusov, there is a very strong possibility that the fire was not started by Napoleon's troops but was organized under the orders of Rostopchin's secret police.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: I have heard that story but I do not believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Rostopchin is a fanatic and he is capable of anything -- however, it doesn't affect what we are talking about. Please go on.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: The point I was trying to make is that I think it is reasonable to say that Your Majesty would not find himself under unbearable pressure, if he decided to make peace with the Emperor, at least at this time.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: For the sake of your argument, let us say that is correct.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: Well, has Your Majesty considered what Napoleon's alternatives might be, if you simply chose to ignore his note?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes, General Kutusov, I daresay that this has been considered and discussed at great length. Napoleon would simply spend the winter in Moscow and continue the campaign in the spring. Another lesser possibility might be to march on St. Petersburg now, although there is some doubt that he has the strength to do this, until he refits his army.  Pause. 115.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: You have my absolute assurance, Your Majesty, that Napoleon does not have the strength to attack St. Petersburg now -- his army is exhausted and ill-supplied, and he would be defeated if he attempted that.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I will accept your assurance, but I'm afraid I don't see your point.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Your Majesty, I am about to make it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Ah, yes -- proceed.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: The point is that I don't think Napoleon will sit in Moscow until the spring! I don't think he can afford to.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: It would be a sensible decision if he were merely commander of the army, but he is also the Emperor of France. Can he afford to stay away from Paris for what will amount to a year by the time he commences his campaign again in the spring? And, even if he might consider this, his lines of communication are over- stretched and vulnerable -- they can be easily cut by our cossacks. Will he then be willing to remain, completely out of touch with Paris - - for a year? The French are like women. You cannot stay away from them for too long. The Tsar sneezes and blows his nose.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well, that is a very interesting idea, General Kutusov, but I can assure you that Napoleon is no beginner at this. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEXANDER (cont'd) Whatever analysis you have done on this situation, I am sure that he has gone over the same ground.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: I have no doubt that he has, Your Majesty, but does he have any strong moves from which to choose?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well, one thing immediately comes to mind, if what you are saying is true -- he would merely withdraw his army from Moscow and return to Poland for the winter.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: Your Majesty has grasped the outlines of his problem in much less time than it took me. This is a crucial point -- and it isa political one, which Your Majesty will be in a far better position to answer than I. Can Napoleon afford to abandon Moscow without signing even the preliminaries of a peace treaty with you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I must confess he would look a bit silly, fighting his way to Moscow and turning right around again.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: Perhaps it would be even more serious than that, Your Majesty. His European confederation is held together by some very slender threads. Your Majesty knows even better than I that Austria and Prussia are very doubtful allies, and the Emperor has reason enough to fear that they will turn on him, at the first sign of weakness.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: If I can presume to go into the Emperor's mind, I believe that he has based his entire campaign strategy on obtaining a peace treaty after the fall of Moscow. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GENERAL KUTUSOV (cont'd) When Vienna fell, there was a peace treaty. When Berlin fell, another treaty. That has always been the rules of the game. But what is he to do now if no treaty is forth- coming? He knows that beyond Moscow, there is nothing, and that, if he withdraws, there remains only a fall into emptiness. Alexander is thoughtful. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What do you think Napoleon will do?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: I, personally, am convinced that he will withdraw his army from Moscow, and attempt to establish himself in Poland for the winter. In the end, he will not allow himself to be cut off from Paris. But I believe that if he is offered any encouragement, by Your Majesty, he will postpone this decision as long as possible. He is a gambler and he will trust to his luck.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: If he withdraws his army in good order, it will be a serious political defeat. But, if he should be caught on the move, with his army, in the full grip of winter, then it will be a catastrophe. If Your Majesty can prolong his hopes for a treaty by silence, be deceit, by any means, for another month, thus postponing his departure, then the graves of his army are already dug in the soil of Russia.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: General Kutusov, I would like to call a meeting of my cabinet tomorrow morning and have you present this idea to them. I think it has merit and is worthy of consideration.  118.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KUTUSOV
dialogues.text: I am at your disposal, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a fine, fall day. Napoleon and a small entourage ar having lunch outside on a balcony overlooking Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Day after day of fine autumn weather was allowed to slip away, while Napoleon waited for the word from Alexander which would never come. The weather was so fine and the temperature so mild that it seemed as if even the season was conspiring to deceive Napoleon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murat and his staff are exchanging gifts with the Cossack officers and soldiers, who treat Murat with great respect Drinks, food and song: the mood is one of expansive warmt in the manner the Russians so easily generate.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His troops fraternized with the enemy and reported them demoralized, and tired of war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mail carriage being unloaded in the Kremlin courtyard Twelve large trunks with Imperial markings are carried inside.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Trunks, bearing dispatches and mail, arrived regularly every day from Paris. It seemed as easy to travel from Paris to Moscow as from Paris to Marseilles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small theatrical performance for Napoleon and his inner circle, performed in a Kremlin room, by a troupe of Frenc artists who were in Moscow at the time of the occupation. They are playing a farce to polite laughter and applause.  119.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Thus, lulled by events, and by realities he could not face, Napoleon seemed to fall into a dream in Moscow, and, amid the dreadful storm of men and element gathering around him, he spent his time discussing the merits of some new verses which he had received, or the regulations for the Comedie Francaise in Paris which took him three evenings to prepare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, alone in his room in the Kremlin. Vacant, immobile, heavy.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon was extremely superstitious and retained a mystical belief in his partnership with fate, a sense that he could only do so much, and that events must somehow complete the decision. And, so it would be in Moscow, where, without confidence and full of apprehension, he would cheerlessly pursue his destiny, unaware that fortune, which had so often smiled upon him, had now abandoned his cause just when he required miracles of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Russian advance guard cavalry moves through the debri the retreat scattered along the sides of the road -- dead and horses, overturned wagons containing the booty taken Moscow, gold candlesticks, porcelain vases, paintings, beautifully bound books, silverware, priceless furniture.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: It was not until October 20, that Napoleon withdrew the Grand Army from Moscow, to begin their thousand mile march into oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon on foot with his army.  120.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He had waited too long. But the execution of his army would not be principally caused by cold or battle, but be starvation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French foragers loading carts, protected by a hundred cavalry. Thirty Cossack horsemen watch from some woods, a few hund yards away.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In order to feed the army in the barren and ravaged wasteland through which it had to march, it was necessary to send large foraging parties deep into the surrounding countryside, protected by strong escorts of French cavalry, against the clouds of Cossacks which flanked and followed the march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A French trooper soothes and strokes his dying horse, giv him a bit of sugar, then shoots him. The shot draws attention of some ragged soldiers, who rush up for a meal are kept at bay by the trooper's pistol.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But, by November 5, the temperature was down to 30-degrees of frost, and French horses were dead. They were not bred to endure such cold and, not being properly shod for ice, had no chance to survive in these conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The starving army stumbles along. Hundreds of Cossacks fl the march, out of musket range, several hundred yards off road.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The cavalry was now on foot and it was a simple matter for the hordes of Cossack cavalry to confine the retreating French to their single road, thus transforming the finest army the world had ever seen into a starving, feverish mob, without purpose. General Famine and General Winter, rather than Russian bullets, would conquer the French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A French soldier, Picart, struggling along with a dog tie his back. His friend, Didier, comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: DIDIER
dialogues.text: Hello there, Picart.

dialogues.speaker: PICART
dialogues.text: Ah, Didier -- you are alive.

dialogues.speaker: DIDIER
dialogues.text: Why are you carrying the dog?

dialogues.speaker: PICART
dialogues.text: His paws are frozen and he cannot walk.

dialogues.speaker: DIDIER
dialogues.text: When you eat him, may I have some?

dialogues.speaker: PICART
dialogues.text: My God -- don't you recognize Mouton -- our regimental dog? I would rather eat Cossack. Didier looks disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen French soldiers around a small fire, cooking bits horse-flesh, and a saucepan full of blood, while four or others fire at a small party of Cossacks, keeping them at distance. The men who are cooking are utterly unconcerned with the fighting.  122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A posting house is crammed full of officers and men and horses. Outside, others are banging on locked doors, trying to ge in, but they are refused, virtually condemning them to de during the sub-zero night. A man on the roof, trying to pull off a plank, draws shot from the inside. Suddenly, a fire breaks out inside and, because of the ho and the way that the doors are nailed up, it becomes an instant disaster. No one can get out. The freezing men on the outside make a feeble effort to o the doors but they have been effectively barricaded from inside. The noise and the flames attract other men who have been huddled in the open and, since they can do nothing, they crowd as close as they can to the flames to warm themselv or cook bits of horse-flesh on the points of their swords

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Christmas tree is still up. Toys. Napoleon, on his hands and knees, plays with his son. Marie-Louise watches happily. An aide enters and whispers something, causing Napoleon to get to his feet and excuse himself.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On January 1st, 1814, France itself was invaded. Now, with a small army of raw recruits, Napoleon would have to face the powerful combination of England, Russia, Prussia and Austria, operating against him together, for the first time. The balance of numbers had tilted irretrievably against him.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A year ago, the whole of Europe was marching alongside of us. Today, the whole of Europe is marching against us.  123.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsar Alexander on the move with his army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French refugees, their belongings on carts. A few miles t the rear, the smoke of a burning village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anxious French townspeople gather around a courier readin war dispatches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserters are arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon spends his last afternoon burning private papers playing with his 3-year old son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon kisses Marie-Louise and son for the last time. H will never see them again. Carriage and escort waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, at the head of his army, marching through the wintry countryside to meet the invading allied army.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: All around him, the sands were giving way, but Napoleon struck back with a brilliance which caused Wellington, much later on, to remark: "The study of the campaign has given me a greater idea of his genius than any other." For two months, Napoleon's small army would bedevil the jittery and uncoordinated allied armies by rapid marches and surprise attacks on their flanks and rear.  124.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The negotiators' meeting at Chatillon.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: During much of the fighting, a peace conference took place at Chatillon, where both sides insincerely raised and lowered their terms with the ebb and flow of the fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon asleep in his chair near a fire. The table in fr of him is covered with maps, papers. His marshals and generals stand at a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Illuminating and illustrating the narration.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But despite the brilliance of his tactics, Napoleon's numbers dwindled and, in desperation, he made a daring and imaginative decision to move eastward, placing himself in the rear of the allied armies. This would cut their long lines of communication but, at the same time, leave open the road to Paris. Napoleon counted on Joseph fulfilling his orders for the defense of the city, so that, if the allies took the bait and marched on Paris, it would offer Napoleon an opportunity for a decisive victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander reading the letter from Talleyrand.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But on March 10th, the Tsar received a note from Talleyrand, revealing the total lack of military preparations in Paris.  125.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russian cavalry patrol captures French courier on snowy, forest road.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On March 23rd, allied patrols captured a courier carrying a letter from Napoleon to Marie- Louise in which he rashly revealed his plans.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Situation map showing Paris, Allies, Napoleon, strung out in that order, and covering the narration.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Although Alexander realized it was essential for Paris to surrender within 24 hours, to avoid the allies being trapped between the walls of Paris and Napoleon's forces which might attack his rear, he chose to gamble, persuading his generals to ignore Napoleon and march on Paris. This crucial decision would bring down Napoleon's empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snowy road near Fontainebleau -- French troops retreati Napoleon's carriage and escort gallop through the troops the head of the column and stop. Napoleon climbs out and confronts General Belliard.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, Belliard, what's this? What are you doing here? Where is the enemy?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: They are at the gates of Paris, sire.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And where is the army?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: It is on this road, sire, following me.  126.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And who is defending Paris?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: Paris is evacuated, sire. The enemy is to enter at nine o'clock tomorrow morning. The National Guard is on duty at the gates.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Paris has surrendered?! I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: Unhappily, it is true, sire.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: But where are my wife and son? What's become of them? Where is Marmont? Where is Mortier?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: The Empress, your son and the whole court left two days ago for Rambouillet. Marshals Mortier and Marmont are probably still in Paris, completing the arrangements. Napoleon starts walking rapidly down the road, in the direction of Paris. The party of senior officers scurry after him.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Well, you've heard what Belliard says, gentlemen -- come, I am going to Paris. Caulaincourt, have my carriage brought up. Come, come, Belliard, turn your men around.

dialogues.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
dialogues.text: But, Your Majesty, we cannot go to Paris now. There are no troops left there.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: No troops? The National Guard is still there -- they will follow me. Things may yet be put right.

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: But, sire, Your Majesty would lay Paris open to being sacked. The enemy is outside the gates with more than 120,000 men. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLIARD (cont'd) Besides this, I left the city under the terms of a treaty and I am forbidden to reenter Paris.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: A treaty? Don't be ridiculous. What treaty is this? Who made it? Who has been giving orders?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: I don't know the details of the treaty, sire, Marshal Mortier sent me word of its having been agreed to, and he said that I was to take the army and make for Fontainebleau.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: But who made this treaty?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: I believe it was arranged by Marshals Mortier and Marmont. I must explain to you that we have had no orders all day. Each marshal has been keeping his own position.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Who sent my wife and son out of Paris?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: I don't know, sire.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: And where is Joseph?

dialogues.speaker: BELLIARD
dialogues.text: I don't know what has happened to Prince Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: What cowardice! What treason! Joseph has ruined everything. How could they all lose their heads. They knew I was coming up fast. Victory was just within grasp. Come, come, turn your troops around, General Belliard.

dialogues.speaker: CAULAINCOURT
dialogues.text: But, sire, we mustn't risk turning Paris into another Moscow.  128.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: There seems little enough danger of that. Come! Come! My carriage! The troops! Another column of troops, withdrawing from Paris, comes i sight. Suddenly, Napoleon stops, sits down by the side of the road, and holds his head.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In defeat, Napoleon would be punished by the Kings of Europe, according to a standard which they would not have applied to each other. He might marry the niece of Marie Antoinette, and call himself an Emperor, but that did not make him one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a comic opera parody of former grandeur, Napoleon marc in a pathetic procession, led by the governor, the prefec and other city officials, cheered by the local population A band of twenty fiddlers -- no brass, no percussion, mar along playing the Elban national anthem. A few hundred of his guards bring up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The treaty of Fontainebleau of April 1814, signed by the allies and Napoleon, in return for his abdication from the throne of France, gave him the token sovereignty of the tiny island of Elba, with the title of Emperor, a yearly income of 2 million francs, an army of 700, and a navy of 3 ships. But in ten months time, even this tiny stake would be sufficient capital to bring this most reckless of all gamblers back into the game for a final, breathtaking spin of the wheel.  129.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glittering garden party at Malmaison. Josephine and Tsa Alexander. Present are: Frederich Wilhelm of Prussia, Francis II of Austria, the Kings of Bavaria. Alexander and Josephine off, walk alone. She wears a low- cut dress.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: After the solitude and semi- banishment of the last four years, Josephine found herself again at the center of Paris society. There would be a crush of crowned and coroneted heads at Malmaison, led by Tsar Alexander. But Josephine's final conquest would be pathetically brief -- in two weeks, she was to die of pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: How delightful it must have been this spot to Napoleon. Could he but pass his life here with you, Madame, he would have nothing to complain of but the too rapid slide of time.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: He loved Malmaison. I think it was the only place he was ever happy and carefree. Alexander inhales the fragrant night air.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: The fall of a great man is a sad sight to behold... He treated me badly but, even in my religion did not not forbid me to bear malice, I would bear him none. I am a better friend of his than he may know.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: You were the only monarch for whom he had both affection and respect.  130.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It was I who secured the sovereignty of Elba for him, at a time when treachery and desertion of his own followers left him at the mercy of those who would have done much worse to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: I am certain you still hold his affection and gratitude. I believe he is only bitter about the desertions to his cause of those who were closest to him -- most particularly, the Marshals. He thought that, by giving them titles and making them rich, he would ensure their loyalty -- but in the end, they thought only of saving their titles and estates. Alexander stops, takes her hands in his, moves very close her, and speaks in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Madame, I hope you will allow me to discuss a matter which I fear may be distasteful to you at the present time, but which, in fairness to yourself and to your children, I feel I must -- and that is the subject of your own properties and pensions. Josephine is, of course, more than happy to discuss this.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPHINE
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Let me be as good a friend to you as Napoleon ever was. If you will but command me, I shall secure all that is due to you and your children -- and even more, should you so desire. He leans forward and kisses her. EXT. ELBA BEACH - DAY A sunny beach on the island of Elba. Napoleon is seated a folding table in front of a tent.  131. He is talking with General Bertrand. A few guards of the escort are visible in the distance. Napoleon has not just heard the news but has been talking about it for hours.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Josephine dead -- how unbelievable! How impossible it is to believe it. She was always physically so strong -- she was never ill a day in her life.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAND
dialogues.text: It is a terrible shock. The silences are punctuated by the sound of the gentle su

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: But did she have the best doctors? Wasn't there any chance at all to save her?

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAND
dialogues.text: I don't know, sire -- she had the Tsar's personal physician.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: She should have had Larrey or Corvisart. They might have saved her... But why didn't anyone even write to me? Can you believe that no one even bothered to write to me? Would you have believed that I should read such news in a newspaper? How incredible!

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAND
dialogues.text: That is incredible.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Ah, my poor Josephine. She was the most alluring, most glamorous creature I have ever known -- a woman in every sense of the word, and she had the kindest heart in the world. She may have been a liar and a spendthrift, but she had something that was irresistible -- she was a women to her very fingertips... How impossible it is to believe that she is dead.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAND
dialogues.text: I have never heard an unkind word about her spoken.  Pause. 132.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I suppose I might blame her for opening her house to the men most responsible to my downfall, but how can I? She was on her own again, she had to look after her own affairs, and how can one blame her for having her head turned by the attention of Kings?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: She made me very unhappy when we were first married, but when we are young we become addicted to the pain of love and, once having experienced it, never want to be cured. For afterwards, we dread the horrible solitude of the heart, the emptiness of feeling... He reaches into his pocket and pulls out a bill. Pause. INT.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Look at this -- how incredible! My last souvenir -- a bill I received just two weeks ago from her couturier -- 6,000 francs...!

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Now I have lost everything that is precious to me. My dearest wife has been locked away by her father, and my poor baby grows up without me.

dialogues.speaker: SCHONBRUNN BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Marie-Louise and General Neipperg, a handsome and virile with a patch over one eye, making love.  133.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Marie-Louise would prove to be a little more than a dull, commonplace, sensual girl, accustomed to obey the dictates of her father, who easily dissuaded her from joining Napoleon, and carefully chose instead as her aide- de-camp, the gallant and dashing General Neipperg, who soon became her lover. They would have two children together before Napoleon's death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grotesquely large nursery in Schonbrunn Palace, over- filled with expensive toys. The King of Rome, now four ye old, sits alone on the floor, playing with some soldiers. Two nursemaids sit at some distance from him, near the window.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon would never see his son again, and the child would grow up in gilded isolation, melancholy, ignored by his mother, in chronic ill-health and haunted by the legend of this father. He would die at the age of 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throne room of the Tuileries Palace. A large group of marshals are swearing their loyalty to the King and kissi his hand. We should see Berthier, Ney, Marmont, MacDonald Lefebver.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: When Louis XVIII returned to Paris in 1814, he was as unknown in France as an Egyptian Pharaoh. Marked by clumsiness and disdain, he quickly proved that the Bourbon dynasty had learned nothing and forgotten nothing. People said that he did not return to the throne of his ancestors but simply ascended the throne of Bonaparte. By 1815, the army and the people were ready to rise against him and welcome the return of Napoleon.  134.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along shot of Napoleon walking with his mother. We are to far away to hear what they are saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold, clear, brilliant moonlit night. Napoleon on the deck, crowded with his troops who are writing proclamatio in long hand.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon set sail, from Elba, on February 26th, 1815, with his small force of 700 soldiers, while the governor of the island, Sir Neil Campbell, was away in Florence. He put his soldiers to work writing out his proclamations in long hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A regiment of government troops bars the road and the fie bordering it. Some 300 yards away, Napoleon's small army faces them. An aide, of the general commanding the government troops, gallops down the road, salutes and dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) General Cannet presents his compliments to the Emperor, and requests that he lay down his arms and surrender himself and his men.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Colonel. Please present my compliments to General Cannet, and tell him that I shall come presently and bring the answer myself. The aide salutes, remounts and rides back. General Cannet speaks to his troops, riding slowly back a forth on his horse.  135.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL CANNET
dialogues.text: Bonaparte is on his way to attempt to illegally reestablish himself over the legitimate government of our King, Louis XVIII. It is our responsibility, as loyal soldiers of France, to prevent him from doing this, by whatever means are necessary. His force numbers less than 700 men. At this remark, voices are heard from the back ranks.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: (derisively) What about us -- don't we count? Napoleon has mounted a horse and approaches the governmen troops at a gallop. He reigns up about 10 yards from thei front ranks.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Hello, men of the 5th -- do you recognize your Emperor?

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: (from the crowd) Yes! Mixed in with this, there are a considerable amount of cheers.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I recognize you -- we are old friends. I know you from Friedland and Borodino. And, you there, Sergeant Monestier, how are you? More cheers from the ranks.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: My good friends, I am told that Marshal Ney has promised the King to bring me back to Paris in an iron cage. I have sent word to my old friend, Marshal Ney, that he can make that a wooden box, if he is able to manage it, but I certainly must refuse an iron cage - - I'm not as young as I used to be, and I can't accept such drafty accommodations! Laughter and cheers from the ranks.  136.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Men of the 5th, your general has invited me to surrender myself and my men, but I come to make you an offer -- Men of the 5th, will you join me? There is a thunderous cheer from the ranks and the men ru forward surrounding Napoleon. Some soldiers fling themsel at his feet, kissing his coat and his hands. Napoleon's e fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (to a grenadier) I shall have to send a message to Louis VXIII, in Paris, and tell him not to send any more troops -- I have enough already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon dines alone at a large table. He picks at his fo in no special order -- dessert, fish, soup, potatoes. He absorbed, reading a thick report.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: After the dizzying magic of the return, came a sense of disenchantment -- and some anxious second thoughts. The allies had quickly patched up the differences that had divided them for almost a year, at the Congress of Vienna, and on which Napoleon had counted to give him some breathing space. To make matters worse, they refused to have any diplomatic dealings, declaring him a criminal beyond the protection of the law. His valet enters the room silently and crosses the long r to the table.

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: Madame Avrillon has arrived, sire.  137. Napoleon listlessly looks up from a spoon full of pudding

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: Oh -- where is she?

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: I have shown her to your bedroom, Your Majesty. Napoleon stirs his coffee and glances at his wrist watch.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (gloomily ) Please ask her to get undressed, and tell her I'll be along as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: (bowing) Yes, sire. He goes back to his report.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Illustrates the narration.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The allies were preparing to move on the frontiers of France with more than a million men. Strung along the Belgian frontier was an army of English and German troops, under Wellington, separated by ten miles from a force of 120,000 Prussian troops, under Blucher. Napoleon calculated the huge Russian and Austrian armies could not reach his Eastern frontiers before July. This gave him the opportunity to use a favorite tactic and strike quickly against Wellington and Blucher, hoping to defeat them separately, before they could unite their forces. On June 16th, Blucher was defeated at Ligny, and Wellington was forced to retreat from Quatre Bras, but neither victory was decisive, nor were they followed up as they should have been, due to Napoleon becoming ill, and to mistakes by his generals. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) But what would prove disastrous for Napoleon, was that he believed the Prussians to be out of the battle for good, and retreating away from Wellington, whereas Blucher, still full of fight, was marching north to join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opposing French and British armies.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: On the morning of June 18th, Napoleon, with 74,000 men faced Wellington with 67,000, ona battlefield near the village of Mount St. Jean, ten miles south of Brussels. Confident that the Prussians were out of action, or contained by Grouchy's pursuing cavalry, Napoleon's only fear was that Wellington would retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wellington and entourage ride along ridge. Troops cheer.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But Wellington had decided to fight it out, on Blucher's assurance that at least one Prussian corps would reach him by mid-day. He had chosen his favorite defensive position, on a rise, where the reverse slopes would shelter his infantry from plunging artillery fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon, surrounded by officers, bent over a map.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon was in no hurry to start the battle and he waited until mid- day to allow the ground to dry, so that his heavy guns could get into position. This was to prove to be a crucial mistake. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) Had the battle begun at day-break, Wellington would probably have been defeated before the Prussians intervened.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Shows position of both armies on the battlefield and Napoleon's plan of attack.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon ignored the warning of his Peninsular war generals about the fire-power of the English infantry, and decided on a frontal attack on the center, preceded by an attack on the Hougoumont farmhouse, which anchored the English right flank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farm is in the valley below the British positions. Fr troops beaten back by the English in fierce fighting.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: In the opening moves of the battle, the French could not dislodge the English from the Hougoumont farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon and his staff have their telescopes trained on w appears as a cloud of dust, at a distance of some six mil The staff talk, somewhat absently, concentrating on their telescopes.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SIMON
dialogues.text: I think it is only some dust blowing. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MARCHADIER
dialogues.text: I though for a moment, then, that I could just make out the color of French uniforms.  140.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SIMON
dialogues.text: Yes -- a bit of blue and red. I thought so, too.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL LABESSE
dialogues.text: Let us hope it is Marshal Grouchy.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MARCHADIER
dialogues.text: How far away do you make it?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SIMON
dialogues.text: I should say, five or six miles.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MARCHADIER
dialogues.text: At least that.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SIMON
dialogues.text: I thought for a moment I could make out the colors of Prussian uniforms. What do you think? All eyes stare with concern through their telescopes. Napoleon puts his telescope down.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: At 12:30 pm, the column approaching on the right flank was identified as Prussian. Napoleon could have called off the battle at this point, but the campaign would have been lost, and he preferred the chance of smashing Wellington before the Prussians could arrive in strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshal Grouchy at breakfast. Dismounted cavalry are alon the sides of the road, as far as the eye can see. All ear are cocked, listening to the distant sound of guns. Grouc looks worried and uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Had Marshal Grouchy maintained aggressive contact with the retreating Prussians, they would have been prevented from entering the battle. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) Having failed to do this, had he now marched his 34,000 men to the sound of the guns, he would have increased Napoleon's army by fifty percent and would most probably have ensured a French victory. But this was not to be, and Grouchy's inadequacies would be the ruin of Napoleon's last battle.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP
dialogues.text: Shows the battlefield, the Prussians coming up, and Grouchy out of the battle.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: With Grouchy's force out of the battle, and the Prussians moving against his flank, Napoleon was in a strategically compromised position, but there was still time to achieve a tactical triumph on the battlefield before the Prussians arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three quarters of a mile behind the battlefield. Napoleon seated in an arm-chair. Dry straw has been spread on the ground around him. He sits with his head in his hands. He is in pain. His staff waits fretfully at a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But Napoleon was painfully ill, and spent most of the day three- quarters of a mile behind the battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshal Ney, mounted and surrounded by his staff, looks through his telescope.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He left the tactical handling of the battle entirely to Marshal Ney, who, having deserted Napoleon the year before at Fontainebleau, was the only one of that group of Marshals who had since then reconciled with him. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) Berthier had committed suicide when he heard of Napoleon's return from Elba, and Ney's eleventh hour switch of allegiance to Napoleon, had left his soldier's mind ina clouded and uneasy state. He would now make tactical blunder after blunder, while gallantly rushing around the battlefield like a young subaltern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French columns march up a slope to the British positions top. Suddenly, a wall of redcoats rise up from behind the protection of the ridge and fires a devastating volley. T French line wavers. A second line of redcoats appears and fires another volley. The French line breaks, and they be to fall back.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: At 1:30, Ney launched the first main attack, when four densely massed infantry columns, unsupported by cavalry or horse artillery, were repulsed with heavy loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Massed columns of French horsemen riding up the slope at slow canter, their helmets and breast-plates glittering l a stormy wave of the sea, when it catches the sunlight. T are riding stirrup, unhurried, confident, deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: At 3:30 pm, Ney misinterpreted movements in the English line as signs of a general retreat and, now, blundered again, sending in the cavalry alone, unsupported by infantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens fire.

dialogues.text: Opens fire.  143.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible losses of horses and men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An incredible stalemate has developed in the battle. Dead men and horses are everywhere. But the British infantry, their defensive squares, hold their fire, and merely exch stares with the hundreds of French heavy cavalry who prow around them, at a distance of no more than twenty yards.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: After two hours of savage fighting, the British infantry had learned that when the French cavalry were close, the artillery stopped. And they also realized that each time they fired a volley, the cavalry would try to break through them, before they could reload. So they stopped firing. A French colonel rides too close to one of the German squares, his horse stumbles and he falls, dazed. Two Brunswick soldiers dash out, take his purse, his watch an his pistols, and then blows his brains out. A cry of "shame" goes up from the nearby British square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon giving orders. Ney, covered with mud and bloodstains, has become a wild-looking creature.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: By 6 pm, Napoleon had entered into the battle himself and was forced to commit 14,000 men of his general reserve to hold up Bulow's Prussians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Imperial Guard infantry being blasted by a wall of British fire, they falter and retreat. The sound of muske balls against the French breast-plates sound like a hail- storm beating on windows.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: At 7:30 pm, Napoleon released 5 battalions of the guard reserve for Ney's final assault. When this failed, the French morale cracked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British cavalry charge.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Wellington put in his cavalry, and the French army broke in panic and ran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ney, now a bloodspattered demon, trying to stop the retre

dialogues.speaker: NEY
dialogues.text: Come on -- follow me and see how a Marshal of France dies! He charges into the battle.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But Ney would survive the battle to be shot for treason by the returning monarchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon on the deck of the "Northumberland" looking at t cliffs of St. Helena. He is depressed by the mass of bare volcanic granite rising steeply out of the sea, barely tw eight miles in circumference.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon escaped from France where he might have met the same fate, and surrendered to the English, hoping for a congenial exile in Britain. But he was sent as a prisoner to the tiny island of St. Helena, in the South Atlantic, a thousand miles from the nearest land. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (cont'd) He would live out the last five years of his life there, amid the petty squabbles of his own entourage, and his captors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gloomy sight, situated in a wild landscape.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His house was a hastily rebuilt collection of buildings originally constructed as cattle-sheds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon dictating his memoirs to Count Bertrand, a large is spread on the floor. The room is overcrowded with book and papers. A rat is noticed and ignored.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His four constricted rooms were infested with rats. His food and wine, and opened mail were subjects of continuous dispute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon stares out at the grey Atlantic, watched by seve British soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His walks were so closely guarded that he eventually gave them up altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Hudson Lowe opens Napoleon's mail.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His gaoler, Sir Hudson Lowe, was a weak, narrow-minded, and petty man, obsessed with the fear his prisoner would escape, though a squadron of ten ships, and a garrison of 3,000 men guarded the island.  INT. 146.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Napoleon, grey-faced and looking very ill, being examined a hearty English naval surgeon. INT.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: His final illness would, until the very end, be dismissed by English doctors as a diplomatic disease.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Count Bertrand, a figure of despair in the dimly-lit room keeps a lonely death-watch. Napoleon stirs. EXT.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: (weakly) Who is there?

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAND
dialogues.text: Bertrand, sire.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I have just had the most vivid... dream... about Josephine.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAND
dialogues.text: Yes, sire?

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: She was sitting there... and it was as if I had last seen her only the night before... She hadn't changed - - she was still the same -- still completely devoted to me... and she told me we were going to see each other again and, never again, leave each other... She has promised me. Did you see her?

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAND
dialogues.text: No, sire... I was asleep.

dialogues.speaker: NAPOLEON
dialogues.text: I wanted to kiss her, but she didn't want to kiss me... She slipped away, the moment I wanted to take her in my arms.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE
dialogues.text: The unmarked grave.  147.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Napoleon died on May 5, 1821. Hudson Lowe insisted the inscription on the tomb should read "Napoleon Bonaparte." Montholon and Bertrand refused anything but the Imperial title -- "Napoleon." In the end, it was left nameless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother, dressed in black, sits alone, a study of gloo and lament. The shutters are closed and the semi-darkness the room is broken by bright slivers of sunlight. The camera moves slowly away from Letizia, to an open portmanteau. It is filled with very old children's things faded toys, torn picture books, wooden soldiers and the T bear Napoleon slept with as a child. FADE OUT.
